David Lammy has set out Labour’s contract with the British public on foreign policy in a speech to Chatham House.
The Conservatives have left us with a tarnished international reputation and reduced influence around the world. But it doesn’t have to be that way. With the right priorities, the right partnerships and the right values under a Labour government, Britain can and will thrive.
Labour’s vision is for a Britain reconnected, for security and prosperity at home. This includes seeking a new UK-EU security pact, strong armed forces and resilience against 21st century threats; pushing for climate action to become a fourth pillar of the UN; and reforming the FCDO after the disastrous merger with DFID, re-establishing the UK as a trusted, reliable and influential partner while protecting Britons abroad.

Debt Cancellation: Low-Income Countries Debate
As the global debt crises cripples the Global South, I secured a debate on debt cancellation for low income countries. It was great to see so many other MPs show support for this cause and contribute to a productive afternoon in Westminster Hall.
I asked the Govt to support my Debt Relief (Developing Countries) Bill which would:
– compel private creditors to accept the same terms as other lenders
– reduce debt burden for the poorest countries
– cost the Treasury absolutely nothing
Spending more on debt servicing than on health or education cannot continue. The UK must act now.
The Second Reading of my Bill is due to be the 14th March 2025.
Low-income Countries: Debt Cancellation – Hansard – UK Parliament

I visited the London Cem Evi Centre in Hornsey with my colleague Feryal Clark, MP for Enfield North. As Chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Alevis, it was great to see the work being done in the local area to support the Alevi community.

The Nationality and Borders Bill also returned to the House of Commons on 22nd March for consideration of its Lords amendments, and I know many people are worried about this dangerous Bill and its implications for refugees and asylum seekers.
As I was abroad, I was unable to vote on Tuesday but rest assured I remain resolutely opposed to this piece of legislation as I have since it was introduced, including at 2nd reading, committee and report stages. You can watch my speech during the Bill’s report stage below.
Unfortunately, the Government voted against all the Lords amendments. By doing so, they voted to make it a criminal offence for Ukrainian families to arrive in the UK without the right papers with a penalty of up to 4 years in prison. They also voted to rip up the International Refugee Convention and pave the way for offshore processing centres for refugees. This is shameful, especially at a time when people across the UK have shown their commitment to helping people fleeing war in Ukraine.
The Bill will now go back and forth between the Commons and Lords until an agreement is reached.

Question to the Minister for Development on Syria
On 19 December 2024, I asked the Minister for Development to offer reassurance that the Government will use all its powers to ensure that minority groups in Syria will be protected from attack from HTS and other hostile actors.

Women’s Branch of the CLP in Parliament
I welcomed the Southgate and Wood Green Women’s Constituency Labour Party to Parliament to have a serious discussion about tackling violence against women and girls in today’s society as we marked International Women’s Day last week. We spoke about the resources local authorities can use to help victims of domestic abuse and the severe impact social media has on cultivating misogynist attitudes among teenage boys and young men. We also discussed the role of the UK Government in supporting women in conflict zones internationally. We took a tour of Parliament where we saw pieces of suffragette history, including the cupboard where Emily Wilding Davison hid in on the night of the 1911 census!
This discussion served as a powerful reminder that there is still a long way to go in creating a safer society for women and girls. Currently there is a worrying level of sexual violence, domestic abuse and harassment experienced by women daily in the UK. By the end of 2023, there were only 2008 convictions for the 67,938 rape offences recorded by the police and data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has shown that almost a quarter of women aged 16-24 experienced sexual harassment last year.
Beyond these numbers are survivors whose lives have not only been deeply harmed by the abuse they have experienced, but also the failing systems they have turned to for support. It is imperative that the Government views the safety of women and girls as an utmost priority over this parliament, so we can strive towards a society where women are empowered rather than inhibited.

I was delighted to visit Morocco on a UK delegation as Shadow Minister for the Middle East and North Africa.
We visited the Parliament of Morocco, and also met with the Speaker of the House of Representatives and with Members of Parliament from the Moroccan Progress and Socialism Party (PPS).

Visit to Mulberry Academy Woodside
Yesterday, I met with Year 9 students and school councillors at Mulberry Academy Woodside.
We had a productive Q&A, discussing a variety of topics. I was asked for my advice for young people, what parliament does, and to explain a typical day at work for me.
It was wonderful to meet so many young people keen to engage with and learn about politics. I hope to come back soon!

Labour votes to #CancelTheCut to Universal Credit – 18th Jan 2021
The Conservatives have chosen to cut support for families in the middle of a pandemic by slashing Universal Credit. The UK has had the worst recession of any major economy on Boris Johnson’s watch – now he is making families pay the price.
Last night, Labour held an opposition day debate. We called on the Government to cancel the cut to protect 6 million families across Britain. As an opposition whip, I was a teller for the vote. We won by a landslide of 278-0.
I joined Catch Up With Cancer in Parliament to share my support for its campaign for a radical new cancer plan that boosts treatment capacity to clear the backlog in cancer treatment and care.

It was wonderful to participate in Parliament Week and visit local schools, including De Bohun Primary School in Southgate. It was great to see pupils engaging in politics from such a young age.
I also enjoyed a visit to Woodhouse College to catch up with A-Level Politics students. We had a great Q&A, including discussing my role as a local MP and shadow minister.
Thank you to teachers and students at De Bohun and Woodhouse for two great visits.

As the Conservative Party continues to be mired in corruption over second jobs and paid lobbying, I am looking forward to the by-election campaign in Old Bexley and Sidcup next month.
I had the pleasure of joining the Labour candidate Daniel Francis on the doorstep meeting voters ahead of the by-election, which is an opportunity for voters to send a message to Boris Johnson and his corrupt government. It’s clear from voters on the doorstep, even lifelong Tory voters, that they feel fed up and taken for granted by Boris Johnson’s government. I look forward to joining the team in Old Bexley and Sidcup throughout the campaign to offer my support over the next few weeks.

I took part in my colleague Taiwo Owatemi MP’s debate on family courts. This is something a number of constituents have made me aware of and I have been raising on their behalf.
It can be deeply distressing and it was therefore very moving to hear the debate and speak up on behalf of my constituents, including those in Westminster Hall for the debate.
I spoke on their behalf about issues with Cafcass, the impact of delays and backlogs in the courts, and parental alienation.

I was delighted to visit Garfield School to speak to Year 2 and present Nurjahan with her prize for winning my Christmas card competition – a very late Christmas present from me!
Thank you to pupils for sharing some lovely festive designs and teachers for organising.

One of Boris Johnson’s MPs, Owen Paterson MP, was found to have taken hundreds of thousands of pounds from a company and then sought to influence ministers to benefit those that were paying him. An independent committee ruled that he should face sanction. He should have apologised and taken his punishment. Instead, the Conservatives voted to scrap the Committee that found him guilty.
Imagine if that happened in any workplace across the country – someone is shown to have acted improperly – but instead of facing disciplinary action, the boss intervened and said, “don’t worry, we’ll get rid of the HR department instead.”
Following immense backlash, the Government U-turned and Owen Paterson has resigned. It’s shameless and shameful in equal measure, and the damage has been done.
For International Day of Persons with Disabilities, it was great to join Disability Rights UK in Parliament to show my support for equal rights for disabled people.

I visited Vahid Beheshti, a British-Iranian dual national, who has been on hunger strike outside the Foreign Office for over 37 days, in protest at the UK Government’s refusal to take action against the Iranian regime by proscribing the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps.
With my Shadow Foreign Affairs colleagues Catherine West and Janet Daby, I shared my solidarity and assured him that the Labour Party is calling for the proscription of the IRGC and will continue to urge the Government to take this important step.

I’ve had lots of emails from constituents about plastic waste and the Big Plastic Count – the biggest ever investigation into plastic waste, which took place in May.
I participated in the Big Plastic Count, and I know many people, businesses and schools in Enfield Southgate did too. It’s clear we need to do more to reduce waste, tackle plastic pollution, and create more reusable options that work for everyone.

The planned closure of Grenoble Gardens Surgery is deeply worrying and I have been raising concerns about this privately and have now responded to the NHS North Central London ICB consultation. You can find my full response below.

Last week, Palmers Green residents and Friends of Broomfield Park shared their concerns with me about the proposed Oktoberfest event in Broomfield Park, and I raised their concerns with Enfield Council officers.
The scale of the event and its impact on surrounding areas would have likely caused major damage to the park and significant disruption to the local community.
I was therefore pleased that the application for Oktoberfest was withdrawn last Thursday and the event will not be going ahead after the concerns of residents were listened to.

Boris Johnson’s resignation is welcome but long overdue for a man who has presided over sleaze and scandal at every turn.
The Conservatives have overseen 12 years of economic stagnation, declining public services and empty promises. We are now stuck with a government that isn’t functioning.
The problems run much deeper than one individual. The public are facing a worsening cost of living crisis, yet due to this Conservative chaos we now face months without a functioning government all the while ordinary peoples’ wages are being stretched week by week by spiralling prices.
We now need a fresh start for Britain that a Labour government will provide.

I am grateful to the Labour Party Independent Complaints Board for clearing my name after a thorough investigation into the allegations against me and I am delighted that the suspension of my Labour Party membership has been lifted.
Throughout this challenging time, my primary focus has been serving the constituents of Enfield Southgate. With this matter resolved, I look forward to returning to Parliament with the Labour whip restored to be the voice of my constituents once again in Westminster.
Bambos Charalambous MP

Thank you Hazelwood Parent Staff Association for inviting me to draw the raffle at the Hazelwood Christmas Fayre.
My highlight was the teachers’ karaoke! Well done Josh, Stella & Steph on your excellent renditions of ‘Last Christmas’ and ‘All I Want for Christmas’ all in aid of the school.

This week, the Government announced that face coverings must be worn on public transport and in shops unless you are exempt. This comes amid the spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant.
I welcome these measures, as we all need to do our bit to ensure we avoid further restrictions, starting by wearing a face covering unless exempt and getting a booster jab if eligible.
Vaccines save lives. They remain our best weapon against the threats of both flu and a new variant of COVID this winter. To learn more about booster jabs and your eligibility, visit Enfield Council’s website below.

I was proud to secure a debate in Parliament on funding and support for classical music, as recent cuts and decisions have been devastating for the industry.
Our classical music scene is a source of pride at home and admiration abroad. But recent cuts and decisions have created massive uncertainty in the industry. During the debate, I raised the BBC Singers, the threat of 20% cuts to jobs in the BBC Orchestras, and the impact of moving the ENO.

My Speech to the Lord Chancellor and Secretary of State for Justice
https://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/House_of_Commons_25_07_24_12_26_23-1.mp4 Above is a section of my speech in the Criminal Law Debate (25/07/2024). The full transcript of my speech is attached here.

It was incredibly moving to speak in the debate today on the legacy of Jo Cox.
I never knew Jo, but I do know from colleagues across Parliament that she epitomised the good in all of us and inspired us to be kinder, fairer and more compassionate to each other and our communities.
During the debate, I raised the issue of loneliness. Jo was passionate about tackling loneliness & this issue has increased during the pandemic, affecting many including refugees separated from families & loved ones due to persecution, war or poverty.
We must continue to take Jo’s lead on this issue and tackle loneliness as we emerge from the Covid-19 pandemic and deliver positive change in our communities, for refugees and all of those affected by loneliness.

On Holocaust Memorial Day, I attended Enfield Council’s Holocaust Memorial Day event at the Dugdale Centre. And in Parliament, I also signed the Holocaust Educational Trust’s Book of Commitment to commemorate the victims of the Holocaust and pay tribute to the survivors.
I pledged to remember all those who were murdered for who they were and stand with people living under persecution for who they are today.
We must never forget the horrors of the past, and we must stand together against hate today.

North Mid Sickle Cell and Thalassemia Centre
On New Years Eve, I joined the Chief Nurse for London, Karen Bonner MBE, to officially open the sickle cell and thalassemia emergency department bypass unit at North Middlesex University Hospital.
I want to thank those who played a huge role in making this bypass unit possible, improving care and securing better outcomes for patients who present to the emergency department with sickle cell disease and thalassemia.

On Children’s Mental Health Week it was important to show my support for Labour’s plan to transform mental health services in the UK.
Children’s futures are being put at risk as demand for mental health services continues to rise. That’s why Labour is committed to providing mental health treatment within a month, specialist support in every school and mental health hubs in every community.

With reports that school spending per pupil has fallen by 9% in real terms since 2009-10, it is extremely concerning that education – the cornerstone for the future of our economy – is not being properly supported and is currently missing the ambition it deserves and desperately needs.
I have been contacted by many constituents, school leaders, and parents in recent weeks who are incredibly disappointed that education funding was missing from the Autumn Statement. I urged the Chancellor to take steps to address this, which you can read below.

I joined MPs from across the House to mark 80 years since the UK first publicly acknowledged what we now know as the Holocaust. The Government’s shocking announcement in December 1942 prompted a spontaneous moment of silence – reported to be the first in the history of the House of Commons chamber.
We owe it to survivors, and to those who were murdered, to remember and take action to prevent prejudice today.

I have watched the recent events unfolding in Israel and Gaza with horror. It is difficult to find the right words at such a distressing time.
I have received hundreds of emails from people in our community over the past two weeks.
You can read my thoughts below.
My statement
Thousands of innocent people have been killed. Many thousands more have been injured. Both these numbers are likely to rise. My thoughts are with the victims and everyone who has been affected by this appalling, and ongoing, violence.
Firstly, as your local MP, I have been in close contact with community leaders and the police to discuss community safety, and to reassure the Jewish and Muslim communities I represent. With Tell Mama and CST reporting over 300% increases in Islamophobic and anti-Semitic incidents, it is absolutely vital we come together as a community to support each other and stand against those who seek to divide us, as we know events in the Middle East cause huge pain in our communities here in the UK.
I unequivocally condemn Hamas’ terrorism and the senseless violence against innocent people that occurred on 7 October.
This was a massacre, reminiscent of pogroms which took place in the 19th and early 20th century. I want to express my sympathy to all grieving families in Israel and across the world, and all those affected, including the British hostages held by Hamas. My thoughts are also with our Jewish community in Enfield Southgate who I know are in deep shock and grief following Hamas’s brutal attacks.
In Gaza, the already dire humanitarian situation is escalating to catastrophe.
Whole neighbourhoods have been razed to the ground, with more than 3,000 people killed due to Israeli airstrikes, including thousands of children. The order that over a million Gazans leave their homes has led to chaos – without international aid, they will face hunger and thirst which will undoubtedly lead to many more deaths. My sympathy is with Palestinian families who have lost loved ones, or who are struggling to get news as to whether their relatives are alive or dead.
I believe we need a negotiated ceasefire immediately – to protect innocent civilians.
The international community has a responsibility to promote this. International law must be upheld. Hostages must be returned to their families. Palestinian civilians need immediate safety from airstrikes. And we urgently need humanitarian aid corridors to be opened so that people can access food, water, medicines, and shelter. If this does not happen immediately, it will be nothing short of a humanitarian disaster.
The world must act before it is too late.
In the long term, we must support progress towards a negotiated settlement based on two states: with a safe and secure Israel alongside a sovereign Palestine. This, now, feels more remote than ever. And as the horrifying backdrop of war continues, the international community must make efforts to ensure all perpetrators of war crimes are held accountable. To be clear: the deliberate targeting of civilians is a war crime, as is the wilful destruction of civilian infrastructure which will undoubtedly lead to loss of civilian life.
This week I have written to the Foreign Secretary on the above points, urging the UK Government to support a ceasefire to protect civilian lives, and for the UK to do all it can to ensure aid reaches Palestinians in desperate need.
Important information, charity links and donations
Charities working in Gaza
I know this conflict will have deeply affected many people in our community, and many have asked how we can come together to help people in Gaza right now.
As the crisis in Gaza escalates, I think often of the Gazans I have met – in particular, the brave staff of Medical Aid for Palestinians (MAP), who are working around the clock to provide life-saving care in the most brutal of circumstances.
MAP have launched an emergency appeal to respond to the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where hospitals are struggling to cope.
Many other charities and organisations are appealing for support too, and you can find some more appeals below.
- The Red Cross – https://donate.redcross.org.uk/appeal/israel-and-occupied-palestinian-territory-appeal
- Save the Children – https://www.savethechildren.org.uk/how-you-can-help/emergencies/gaza-israel-conflict
- UNICEF – https://www.unicef.org/appeals/state-of-palestine
- World Food Programme – https://www.wfp.org/support-us/stories/palestine-appeal
FCDO Travel Advice
In the past two weeks, my office has supported constituents and their families who were stranded in the region following Hamas’s terrorist attacks.
The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office is regularly updating its travel advice, including for Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories, Lebanon, Egypt and Jordan.
You can find the latest advice on the FCDO website here: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice
This page was last updated on 20 October 2023.

I voted against the Government’s anti-democratic Elections Bill. I know many constituents are rightly concerned about this Bill. This legislation will reverse decades of democratic progress in the UK and make it harder to working class, disabled, older and Black, Asian and ethnic minority people to vote. It will require voters to show voter ID, which risks denying millions of people their democratic right to vote – while also being a total waste of taxpayers’ money.
My Labour colleagues and I voted against the Bill to protect democracy.

It was an honour to cut the ribbon and mark the opening of North London’s Hospice’s latest shop in Enfield!
These shops play a crucial role in raising vital funds needed to support hospice services, providing care and comfort to those in need. The success of these shops is a testament to the hard work and dedication of local volunteers and the staff at North London Hospice.
A special thanks to Anita, Victoria, Carl and all the amazing volunteers who have out their time and effort to make this hop a reality. I wish you the best of luck in making it a huge success!

Finally, it was an honour to attend the debate in Parliament this week on the case of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe.
I received many emails, letters and messages from constituents sharing their support and solidarity with Nazanin’s family, and urging me to call on the Foreign Secretary and the Prime Minister to do everything they can to bring Nazanin home for Christmas.
The situation is heart breaking and while I didn’t get a chance to speak in the debate, I was proud to represent the people of Enfield Southgate in calling for the Government to free Nazanin.
Nazanin, Richard and their family’s strength and determination is extraordinary, and I hope that one day it is matched by their government.

I was at the despatch box this week to oppose the dangerous Nationality and Borders Bill at report stage and third reading.
This Bill is a sham, and I was proud to voice Labour’s opposition to its draconian and outlandish measures that cost the taxpayer and fail to solve the problem of dangerous crossings.
I know many constituents are concerned about measures in this Bill, including proposals that allow the Home Office to deprive UK nationals of citizenship without warning. I shared my deep concerns about this and many other proposals in Parliament, in my final act as Shadow Immigration Minister.
I believe the Bill is a smoke-and-mirrors trick designed to deflect attention from the Conservative Government’s failings and incompetence in the area of asylum and refugee protection.
The Bill passed with support of Conservative MPs and will now progress to the House of Lords.

It was great to go up to Erdington in Birmingham ahead of the March by-election. I joined MPs, activists and supporters campaigning on the doorstep for the local Labour candidate Paulette Hamilton.
I spoke to lots of former Tory voters who told me they are switching to Labour over partygate and the cost of living crisis.

Haringey Civic Centre Groundbreaking Ceremony
Yesterday, I attended the groundbreaking ceremony of Haringey Civic Centre’s restoration.
Marking the redevelopment of the civic centre is an exciting step towards improving the sustainability of Haringey Council’s offices and access to residents and visitors to ready the building for the future. The redevelopment will ensure the Civic Centre reopens with a larger footprint to serve residents as a hub for Council services and offer public cultural spaces.
It is also wonderful to see how the Council have used the online consultation, Civic Voices, to engage with local residents and use their views to design this new and improved Civic Centre, while preserving history and celebrating important memories.

It was wonderful to visit the Ruth Winston community centre in Palmers Green.
I met members enjoying the beginners computer class, which helps older and vulnerable people learn vital computer skills, joined in with a Spanish class and got to test out my own Spanish (Gracias Luis!) and finally went along to the common room where there was scrabble, hot drinks and cakes.
Thank you to everyone at the Ruth Winston Centre for a great visit.

Last year I nominated the North Middlesex University Hospital Neonatal Team for an NHS Parliamentary Award for their work with families and new-borns at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. I am really proud that this week the team were awarded the national award at the NHS Parliamentary Awards ceremony. The fact that the team made sure that families could stay connected during the pandemic is a testament to the vital work that the hospital does for our local community.

As Shadow Immigration Minister, I was in Parliament to hear the Home Secretary’s statement on the deaths of more than 20 people in the Channel this week. It’s clear that we need to take a new approach to fix the asylum system, which has been broken by over a decade of Conservative government.

Closure of Rail Ticket Offices in Enfield Southgate
After hearing from constituents, the strength of feeling in our local community is clear. The closure of local train station ticket offices will be bad for safety, bad for passengers, and bad for staff.
I have now responded to London Travelwatch’s consultation and you can read it in full below.
Sent via email – London Travelwatch
I am writing on behalf of my constituents in Enfield Southgate to object to the proposed closure of ticket offices at Great Northern, including ticket offices at Hadley Wood, Enfield Chase, Grange Park, Winchmore Hill and Palmers Green in my constituency.
From speaking to constituents about this issue, the strength of feeling in our local community is clear. The closure of these ticket offices will be bad for safety, passengers, and staff. I have set out the reasons for my objection in more detail below.
Impact on passengers
Everyone should have the right to travel with freedom and confidence. I am therefore deeply concerned that ticket office closures would cause a significant worsening of the facilities and support offered to vulnerable passengers, including disabled, Deaf and older people.
Already, disabled people face numerous barriers in accessing the rail network and are three times less likely to travel by rail than non-disabled people.
For example, research by the Royal National Institute of Blind People (RNIB) has found that only 3% of people with sight loss said they could use a ticket vending machine without problems and 58% said it was impossible. At the same time, 23% of disabled adults and 6% of non-disabled adults are unable to use the internet, and wheelchair user discounts can only be purchased at ticket offices.
Closing ticket offices will require all passengers to purchase tickets online or through Ticket Vending Machines (TVMs) at the station.
For many of my constituents, online ticketing is simply not an option and using TVMs is difficult and not an accessible alternative. Indeed, the ticket office is the only way for passengers to ensure that they get the appropriate and best value fare for their journey. I recently met with the Hadley Wood Rail Users Group and they highlighted how passengers are unable to book advance tickets at TVMs but can at ticket offices. As you know, advance tickets are often a fraction of the price and removing this option could therefore hit people already struggling with the cost of living crisis.
One of my constituents, who is in her seventies, also told me that the “closing of ticket offices is awful. I am 77 and so many folks I know who are older with worse problems than me” will be affected.
She urged me to “Please keep ticket offices open, as doing everything online is not always a safe option. It seems we are no longer able to communicate verbally which has a huge impact on mental health.”
The Enfield Over 50s Forum also shared with me their concern about the negative consequences of ticket office closures for their members.
They reported that “apart from being a mine of information and expert advice, it is a point of human contact and a presence in what can be an unmonitored space. This is especially important as, with increasing age, people often find travelling stressful. They may need to check the journey is viable, get information on options or about platforms, as limited mobility makes unnecessary moving up and down steps over-demanding.
“Clearly, fear of travelling will further fuel isolation when many families are now widely dispersed and visits to children and grandchildren, for example, should be as stress free as possible.”
For disabled passengers, the ticket office is about more than just tickets. At many stations ticket office staff are the only staff present, and their responsibilities often include assisting passengers on to trains, including with ramps where required and meeting them off the train.
They are the first point of contact when disabled passengers arrive at the station. Multifunctional staff who roam around the station are not an accessible alternative. For example, disabled people with mobility or energy impairments cannot travel through the station to try and find assistance, and blind and visually impaired passengers may struggle to identify a member of staff. Ticket offices are also the only designated point in the station with a hearing induction loop.
Another constituent wrote to me and shared her concerns about removing ticket offices for vulnerable passengers. She said: “I am concerned for the safety and security of vulnerable passengers and those with impaired sight who have difficulty using ticket machines or perhaps even negotiating the entry gates and stairs.”
A recent audit by the Office of Rail and Road found that only 51% of disabled passengers were able to successfully receive assistance using help points. A system that fails half its disabled users cannot be implemented.
For the reasons outlined, I am very concerned that people in my constituency will be unable to access the assistance they need as a result of these ticket office closures and I urge Great Northern to reconsider these proposals.
Impact on staff
Ticket office staff provide a valuable service to the community. I understand that the proposals from Great Northern mean staff who work in ticket offices will move to the concourse or a location in the station where they can provide additional support to passengers.
I have serious concerns about how this would work at stations in my constituency.
As one constituent, who contacted me recently, said: “I live within walking distance of Winchmore Hill station and my immediate thought was ‘How could the staff be redeployed within the station if the ticket office was permanently closed?’ I can understand how this could be done at a large station where there is a main concourse and multiple platforms, but I cannot see how this would work at a small station such as Winchmore Hill so I can only assume that the station would be permanently unmanned with the ticket office staff subsequently losing their jobs.”
I share these concerns. I am deeply worried about the job security of station staff in my constituency, and fear that these ticket office proposals are merely a prelude to job losses.
Recently, speaking in the House of Commons, the Rail Minister said: “In the event that there are some [staff] that don’t wish to make that transition, then of course the train operators will need to look to that [job losses].”
And I understand that Great Northern are currently running a staff consultation on the proposed changes.
I have not received any assurances about the job security of staff, and I think it is difficult to see how train operators would be able to demonstrate that their proposals would make cost savings, unless there is the intention to reduce staffing.
I am wholly opposed to any cuts to station staffing. I believe any supposed cost savings cannot be used to justify a policy that will worsen passenger service, accessibility, safety, security and access to the rail network and public transport.
Safety
Staffed ticket offices have an important role in supporting passenger safety and security. Ticket offices provide a place of safety for both staff and passengers. Requiring staff to undertake transactions out on the platform puts both passengers and themselves in a more vulnerable position.
Ticket office staff are trained and experienced in dealing with difficult incidents and the presence of staff deters abusive and anti-social behaviour.
Ticket office staff provide support and assistance to passengers during times of disruption or in response to emergencies and their role often includes carrying out safety and security checks at the station throughout the day.
As passenger watchdogs will be aware, there is a consistent theme emerging from research, which is that passengers like and value the presence of staff. I have shared evidence from constituents throughout this response that demonstrates this fact. Having staffed ticket offices supports passenger perceptions and feelings around safety, and closing ticket offices could lead to passengers no longer feeling safe when travelling.
As the Enfield Over 50s Forum said: “Empty stations, especially at night and off peak, are a gift to those with criminal intent, especially as travellers may well have money and cards to steal and be unable to defend themselves or run away. This is a major cause of anxiety.”
Closing ticket offices will therefore inevitably, in my view, discourage many from travelling on the rail network.
Length of consultation period
Finally, I was disappointed that the length of the consultations on such a consequential change to our rail networks has been limited to only 21 days.
Given the huge scale of public concern around this issue in my constituency, the fact that passengers and staff have had only three weeks to put forward their views is simply not good enough. They want their views to be heard and properly considered.
Ultimately, for the reasons outlined above, I believe London Travelwatch must reject the proposals from Great Northern to close ticket offices in my constituency at Hadley Wood, Enfield Chase, Grange Park, Winchmore Hill and Palmers Green.
Bambos Charalambous MP for Enfield Southgate

Earlier this week, I joined colleagues from across Parliament to raise awareness of One Punch Assaults on One Punch Awareness Week. One punch assaults can have a devastating impact and it was great to see parliamentarians from all parties come together in support of this important campaign.

Before Half Term, I visited Broomfield School and enjoyed speaking to Year 7 and 8 students and staff about the changes taking place in the school.
It was also wonderful to see everyone supporting the Turkey and Syria appeal as part of the school’s non-uniform day.

On White Ribbon Day and International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, I was proud to support the campaign to end the epidemic of violence against women.
Women are not safe because of the actions of violent men, and White Ribbon Day is a reminder that all men can help to end violence against women & girls by never committing, excusing or remain silent about it.

I was proud to support Less Survivable Cancers Awareness Day, to raise awareness about the six less survivable cancers – cancers of the liver, lungs, brain, oesophagus, stomach, and pancreas.
Over 90,000 people are diagnosed with one of these six cancers every year in the UK and they account for over 40% of all common cancer deaths. Currently, only 16% of people diagnosed with a less survivable cancer will live for 5 years or more after diagnosis.
Early diagnosis is crucial in saving lives and it was great to speak to Monica from the Liver Trust about the importance of closing the deadly cancer gap for less survivable cancers.

Since 2016, sewage has been dumped in our waters every two-and-a-half minutes.
Last year, there were 824 sewage dumps a day across the country.
Right now, not one English river is classed as being in a healthy condition.
Under the Conservatives, water companies have not only been given the green light to dump sewage and neglect our vital water infrastructure, but they have also rewarded them for it, by allowing shareholders to walk away with billions in dividends and with bumper bonuses for negligent water bosses.
In Parliament, I voted for Labour’s Water Quality Bill to clean up our waters and end the Tory sewage scandal once and for all.

Firefighters are there for us all year round and it was an absolute pleasure to visit Southgate Fire Station and meet with the Green Watch who will be working over the festive period.
During my visit, I learned about the danger of fires from lithium batteries in e-scooters and electric bikes. With three deaths this year, and around 60 injuries, this is London’s fastest-growing fire risk according to the London Fire Brigade.
As e-bike and e-scooter usage grows, the key safety concern comes from unregulated, unsafe products – usually bought online – causing fires. This includes chargers, batteries & conversion kits.
I have now raised my concerns with the Department for Transport and urged the government to consider better regulation to protect people from further harm.

I met bus drivers in Palmers Green to hear their concerns about remote sign on, a worrying practice that means drivers no longer start their shift at a depot. Signing on remotely means that drivers do not have access to basic facilities, such as toilets, canteens or break rooms, which increases health and safety risks including fatigue.
I’m supporting Unite the Union’s campaign against remote sign on, as it is bad for drivers, bad for passengers and bad for health and safety.

The Government has finally shelved its shambolic proposals to close train station ticket offices across the country.
Over the summer, I campaigned alongside many of you to oppose these damaging plans, which would have seen 5 ticket offices in our constituency closed. I am delighted that common sense has prevailed.
Back in July, I shared my concerns that closing our local train station ticket offices would be devastating for passengers, jobs and safety. The proposals outlined would have seen 5 ticket offices in our constituency closed, including Hadley Wood, Enfield Chase, Grange Park, Winchmore Hill and Palmers Green.
I also responded to the London Travelwatch consultation on behalf of constituents, raising the huge public concern about this issue, including around accessibility and access to the rail network for vulnerable people. You can find my full response here to the consultation here: https://www.bambos.org.uk/consultation-response-on-train-station-ticket-offices/
The strength of feeling in our community, and across the country, was clear.
I am therefore delighted these damaging plans have now been dropped. Thank you to all the constituents who raised their concerns with me and everyone who campaigned on this important issue.

The Conservative Government’s complacency is creating a cost-of-living crisis for the people of Enfield.
I’m incredibly concerned that people are being squeezed from all sides – with tax rises for working people while food, petrol and energy prices soar. At the same time, the Chancellor has decided to cut taxes for banks and big companies like Amazon.
The Budget failed to deliver for local people in Enfield Southgate; from next year our taxes will be the highest they’ve been in decades, and yet there was no plan to help our public services – with fewer police on streets, growing class sizes, and longer waits to access hospital treatment.
In contrast, a Labour government would tax fairly, spend wisely and get our economy moving to support working families and businesses.

I was proud to join the National Autistic Society this week to support their campaign for more investment in autistic children’s futures. Many autistic children are waiting years for support in school and without action, they will continue to fall behind.
I strongly believe the upcoming SEND review is an opportunity to fix this, and I will continue to campaign for better, more targeted support and funding for SEND children and their families.

This World Mental Health Day, it was great to see Labour reaffirm our commitment to give mental health the same priority as physical health. A Labour government will transform mental health support in the UK by:
- Guaranteeing treatment within a month
- Recruiting 8,500 new mental health staff
- Early intervention in every community
- Specialist support in every school
- Improve service quality and give mental health its fair share of funding

Disabled children are living without the essential equipment they need due to delays in assessment. Without vital equipment, such as wheelchairs, beds, and specialist seating, children’s conditions worsen resulting in complex surgery or interventions which could have been prevented.
I recently met a family in Enfield Southgate affected by lack of specialist equipment and raised their concerns with the Government during Business Questions.

According to the Independent, 1,200 asylum seekers have waited more than five years due to lengthy delays in the asylum system – and 399 have been left in limbo for more than a decade.
I am demanding to know what the Home Office is doing to address the continuous delays that have put vulnerable people’s lives on hold while generating higher costs to the taxpayer.
I spoke with the Independent this week about this awful government incompetence.

During Heart Unions Week, I was proud to support our trade unions and the incredible work they do, fighting for the rights of workers across the country and helping to create a fairer economy.
I believe that every worker needs a union, as your union is there for you when you need it, and because we’re stronger when we stand together.
Labour also announced its New Deal for Working People, to ensure work will be more secure and better-paid under a Labour Government by:
✔️ Ending Fire and Rehire.
✔️ Day 1 rights.
✔️ Family friendly work, work-life balance.
✔️ Banning zero hours, right to regular hours.
✔️ Stronger union rights.
✔️ Raising pay and conditions for all.

As Shadow Middle East Minister, I spoke in a Westminster Hall Debate on the conflict in Yemen and children’s rights, as Save The Children estimates that 11 million children in Yemen are in dire need of humanitarian assistance.
Children in Yemen face acute malnutrition, displacement and disease, with the near collapse of the health system. During the debate, I outlined how we all share a responsibility to address this dreadful situation. The UK has a unique role to play on Yemen, as the penholder for Yemen on the UN Security Council, and I urged the Minster to commit to protecting children’s rights, because we cannot sit back and allow a generation of children in Yemen to have their childhoods stolen.

People on the ground in Sana’a are facing water shortages, long queues for fuel and the terror of bombing raids. I asked the Minister to provide an update on what is being done to end the Saudi blockade so that people on the brink of starvation in Yemen can get the humanitarian aid they desperately need.

Covid-19 Day of Reflection
Sunday the 9th of March marked Covid Reflection Day, a time to remember the lives lost during the pandemic. I would like to pay tribute to the sacrifices made by our community and brave frontline workers in Southgate and Wood Green.
Marking the fifth anniversary of the pandemic, I paid a visit to the Covid Memorial Wall earlier this week, where families honour their loved ones and the 247,458 people who died from coronavirus.

The world is watching Iran and the appalling violence the regime has unleashed on protestors since the death of Mahsa Amini.
As the regime uses the death penalty to supress the protests, we must stand with the brave Iranian protestors and their demands for the fundamental freedom to live their lives as they choose.
In the House of Commons, I read the names of those at risk of execution.
The Iranian regime must be held accountable for every crime it has committed, including the abhorrent use of the death penalty.
In collaboration with Amnesty, I’ve written on behalf of the Labour Party to the Judiciary in Iran and the Iranian Embassy to condemn the executions of protestors and urge the regime to quash all death sentences.
The courage of protestors across Iran is extraordinary, but we cannot just pay tribute to their courage, we must also stand with them and support them.
That’s why I’ve been delighted to meet Iranian activists in the UK and listen to their experiences and demands, and will continue to do so as we urge the UK to do everything it can to hold the regime to account.

For 37 years Aldermans Pharmacy has been a cornerstone of our community in Palmers Green and throughout this time Mr Shah has been an unwavering presence and source of support.
As Atul retires after more than three decades of service to our community, I visited the pharmacy to thank him on behalf of residents.
I know people across Palmers Green and beyond will join me in wishing Mr Shah the very best for the future.

Women’s Branch of the CLP in Parliament
I welcomed the Southgate and Wood Green Women’s Constituency Labour Party to Parliament to have a serious discussion about tackling violence against women and girls in today’s society as we marked International Women’s Day last week. We spoke about the resources local authorities can use to help victims of domestic abuse and the severe impact social media has on cultivating misogynist attitudes among teenage boys and young men. We also discussed the role of the UK Government in supporting women in conflict zones internationally. We took a tour of Parliament where we saw pieces of suffragette history, including the cupboard where Emily Wilding Davison hid in on the night of the 1911 census!
This discussion served as a powerful reminder that there is still a long way to go in creating a safer society for women and girls. Currently there is a worrying level of sexual violence, domestic abuse and harassment experienced by women daily in the UK. By the end of 2023, there were only 2008 convictions for the 67,938 rape offences recorded by the police and data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has shown that almost a quarter of women aged 16-24 experienced sexual harassment last year.
Beyond these numbers are survivors whose lives have not only been deeply harmed by the abuse they have experienced, but also the failing systems they have turned to for support. It is imperative that the Government views the safety of women and girls as an utmost priority over this parliament, so we can strive towards a society where women are empowered rather than inhibited.

This week saw the publication of Baroness Louise Casey’s review into the Met Police. The report is damning but not surprising. It details how racist, sexist and homophobic abuse has run rife in the Met, with victims let down and trust in the police shattered.
I believe the Home Secretary must take action to address these failings, because without urgent and far-reaching reform, the Met will not regain the trust of people in our community in Enfield and communities across London.

Following the tragic death of Mahsa Amini, I shared my solidarity on behalf of the Labour Party with ordinary Iranians – particularly women and girls – who are clamouring for change against a regime which restricts the liberty and vitality of its people.
Sanctions against Iran are welcome, but the UK must also do more to support Iranian civil society and independent journalism.

It was a pleasure to visit HSBC’s Enfield Town branch and see their ‘Safe Spaces’ initiative in collaboration with domestic abuse charity Hestia’s UK Says No More campaign which helps victims of domestic abuse seek advice and support in all branches. It was great to meet Sevgi and her excellent team, and see their important work in branch.

The hospitality sector expects to have lost 650,000 jobs by February 2021 – many of those affected will be young people. With nearly 1 in 7 young people claiming benefits, much more needs to be done to get young people back into work. I will challenge ministers as to what they are doing to support young people find work.

As the humanitarian crisis continues following the earthquakes in Turkey and Syria, it was deeply moving to speak in Parliament this week about the tragedy that is unfolding in the region.
Two weeks have passed since the earthquakes first hit, and humanitarian needs continue to escalate as the scale of the devastation is brought to light. My thoughts continue to be with all those impacted by this tragedy, including people in Enfield Southgate with family and friends in the region.
Syria is now a crisis within a crisis.
One of the world’s most vulnerable populations, who have endured 12 years of brutal conflict, now face further desperation. We must not turn our back on millions who were already in catastrophic conditions before natural disaster struck.

To mark the King’s Coronation, I joined some local street parties and it was great to see residents come together and share this experience. We had absolutely perfect weather for parties in Beech Road N11 and South Lodge Drive N14, and it was great to see all generations enjoying the day, sharing wonderful homemade food and making memories. The music and the bunting were pretty good too!

Aaron Gayle Court Opening
It was wonderful to open Aaron Gayle Court in Wood Green today with Joanne McCartney AM, Leader Cllr Peray Ahmet, Deputy Leader Cllr Sarah Williams, and the Deputy Mayor for Housing Tom Copley.
With 23 new homes for Haringey, Aaron Gayle is part of Haringey Council’s programme to deliver 3000 new council homes by 2031.
Well done to everyone involved!

The undemocratic Elections Bill returned to Parliament this week, which will make it harder for working class, older, disabled and BAME people to vote.
Many constituents have contacted me about this Bill, which will reverse decades of democratic progress in the UK, bring in voter ID and allow foreign political donations to flood our electoral system.
I voted against the Bill on Tuesday alongside Labour colleagues, and also raised my concerns on behalf of blind and partially sighted voters who will face new barriers around access to equipment when voting if this Bill is implemented.

Last year, Conservative MPs shamefully voted to allow water firms to continue sewage dumping, having blocked a Labour-backed amendment to the Environment Bill that would have sought to progressively eliminate sewage dumping into our natural environment.
We’re seeing the impact of this decision now – with a water system that is ageing and at bursting point due to Tory negligence.
Families across the country should be able to enjoy where they live, work or holiday, without having to worrying about encountering filthy sewage as a result of water firms being allowed to cut corners.

On World Aids Day, we remember those who have lost their lives to HIV-Aids and to stand in solidarity with everyone battling the virus today.
Together, we will continue the fight against discrimination, to achieve better healthcare, and to end the stigma attached to the disease.

World Book Day 2025!
Today is World Book Day!
As the single biggest indicator of a child’s future success, reading for fun matters. It gives children a sense of agency, choice, and empowerment.
Well done to all the parents, carers, librarians, and teachers helping children in Southgate and Wood Green pick up a book & discover reading in their own way!

It was wonderful to visit the Memory Lane Cafe and Carers Club at Our Lady of Lourdes Church in Arnos Grove.
Every Friday, the self funding club offers vital support and a fun, welcoming environment for people suffering from Alzheimer’s and Dementia, and their carers. Thank you to Mandi and Adrian and everyone involved for all their incredible work for our community.

My Speech in the King’s Speech debate
I had the chance to speak on the policies announced in the King’s Speech, where I noted the importance of fixing the shortage of private and council housing as well as the new Renter’s Reform Bill. I look forward to the positive impacts in housing, community safety and equality that our new Government’s legislative programme will engender. Attached above is a short section of my speech.
Here is the link to my speech on Hansard

The execution of British-Iranian man Alireza Akbari is a barbaric act of politically motivated murder by the Iranian regime.
I spoke from the despatch box on behalf of Labour and urged the UK Government to take robust action against the Iranian regime, including proscribing the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which is behaving like a terrorist organisation and poses a growing threat here in the UK.

Visit to Our Lady of Lourdes Primary School
I had a lovely visit to Our Lady of Lourdes on Friday to meet their school council! We spoke about the similarities in how we were both elected, how children can support their community and what issues matter most to them.
It was great to hear about the positive changes they have made to their school already – introducing reading buddies, improving their facilities, fundraising, and starting a calm club.
Well done to all the school councillors at Our Lady of Lourdes!

After days of violence early this month, the announcement of a ceasefire in Gaza last week was welcome news.
As the Shadow Middle East Minister, I called on the UK Government to ensure the ceasefire holds, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza is addressed, and steps are taken to establish a meaningful peace process based on two states.

I was pleased to join Afzal Khan MP and Anneliese Dodds MP this Ramadan, as we reaffirm our commitment to tackling Islamophobia. Labour is the party of equality and anti-racism and we are committed to tackling Islamophobia in society.
It’s time for the Conservatives to step up and do the same.

As we approach May’s local elections, the Government continues to show it is focusing on the wrong things.
For nearly four decades, Channel 4 has created an endless list of brilliant, progressive and world-leading programmes. It is a great British success story, and doesn’t cost the public a penny.
And yet at a time when the Conservative Government should be focused on helping people during the biggest cost of living crisis in decades, with millions of people struggling to pay their bills, the Tories are obsessed with privatising Channel 4.
It’s a shameful decision and many constituents have contacted me to share their anger this week. Labour will fight it.

Letter to Foreign Secretary
As the decision to ban UNRWA comes into effect, I have signed a cross-party letter to the Foreign Secretary to call for intervention and to protect humanitarian aid going to Gaza.
As the decision to ban UNRWA comes into effect, I have signed a cross-party letter to the Foreign Secretary to call for intervention and to protect humanitarian aid going to Gaza.
On New Years Eve, I joined the Chief Nurse for London, Karen Bonner MBE, to officially open the sickle cell and thalassemia emergency department bypass unit at North Middlesex University Hospital.
I want to thank those who played a huge role in making this bypass unit possible, improving care and securing better outcomes for patients who present to the emergency department with sickle cell disease and thalassemia.
I had the privilege of attending the Compassionate Neighbours six-year celebration at North London Hospice Enfield on the 12th of December.
The Compassionate Neighbours model is a volunteer led support programme that assists people in the community with life-limiting illnesses to overcome the physical and mental barriers that stop them actively participating within their community.
Having an illness can often feel very lonely for individuals, and the Compassionate Neighbours model offers thoughtful support for those who are socially isolated, so it was an honour to join people from North London Hospice and commemorate the model’s success.
As part of T-Levels Week, on the 6th of December, I had the pleasure of opening the new T-Level Centre at Barnet and Southgate College’s Southgate campus. The newly refurbished centre will act as a hub for developing the workforce of tomorrow with facilities for teaching Engineering, Computing and IT, and Healthcare Science.
Studies here will be supported by state-of-the-art healthcare facilities and T-Level tutor experts to aid students in their courses.
Well done to Neil Coker, their CEO and principal, and all of his colleagues at Barnet and Southgate College! Good luck to all of the students who go on to study their T-Levels here!
On the 11th November, I attended the Act of Remembrance at Broomfield Park. It was an honour to speak and lay a wreath at this event to pay tribute to the brave men and women who fought for our freedom.
Lest we forget.
To mark the UN International Day of Education, I secured a Westminster Hall debate to discuss the importance of education in our societies and how disruption impacts the next generation. Listen to the highlights of my speech here:
On the 13th January 2025, I spoke in a general debate on Hospices and Palliative Care to discuss the extraordinary work carried out by North London Hospice and Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospice. Financial challenges faced by hospices outline the importance of long-term reform to the hospice funding model.
Read my speech here: Hospice and Palliative Care – Hansard – UK Parliament

I have been in the West Bank and East Jerusalem on a delegation organised by the Council for Arab-British Understanding (Caabu) and Medical Aid for Palestinians, alongside other Labour MPs.
It has been a busy and informative trip, learning about the extensive discrimination faced by Palestinians and the importance of ending the occupation so that Palestinians and Israelis can enjoy security, dignity, and human rights.
It was a humbling experience meeting the family of Shireen Abu Aqla, the Al-Jazeera journalist who was killed earlier this month. Anton, Shireen’s brother, handed us a letter demanding international backing for an independent inquiry into Shireen’s killing and accountability for her death.
We also met staff at the Saraya community centre in the Old Town and the long established residents of the Sheikh Jarrah district of East Jerusalem to hear about settler violence and evictions.
Day 2 started with a visit to a Bedouin village in the E1 area of the West Bank which relies on a weekly mobile medical centre from Medical Aid for Palestinians. The portacabin used for medical appointments, part funded by the British Consulate General in Jerusalem and other international donors, had a demolition notice on it.
We later visited Beita, near Nablus, with the Palestine Red Crescent Society to hear about attacks on Palestinians protesting against illegal settlement outposts, and we also heard testimony from two terrified families in Burin whose homes had been subjected to settler violence.
We finished the day with an excellent discussion with Meretz MK Mossi Raz about the future of peace.
On Day 3, I had the pleasure of meeting Dr Amal Jadou, Palestinian Deputy Foreign Minister in Ramallah. We learned more about the Palestinian Authority’s vision for the future and the challenges it faces in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
On a busy final day, we saw the impact of the fence on the community of Al Walaja, visited Al Arroub refugee camp to hear of the excellent work done by the UN Relief and Works Agency, and then heard testimonies in Hebron from former IDF soldiers now part of Breaking the Silence.

It has been 2,000 days since Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was detained in Iran and separated from her family.
She has been held hostage for crimes she didn’t commit. It is shameful that the sins of the British government should be allowed to sit for so long on the shoulders of ordinary, innocent citizens and their families. I joined Amnesty UK this week in Parliament to call on the government, after more than five years, and five different foreign secretaries, to finally act and free Nazanin.

I am extremely disappointed that the Government has dropped the Animal Welfare (Kept Animals) Bill. This is an issue close to my heart and something that constituents regular contact me about. This is another broken Tory promise after they promised to crack down on illegal puppy farms and animal smuggling.
You can read my full response to this below.

1st December was World AIDS Day and I was proud to wear the red ribbon.
2021 marks 40 years since the first diagnosed cases of HIV in Britain, and this week we came together to remember those who have lost their lives to HIV-AIDS and fought for the right to healthcare.
We now have the tools to end the stigma around HIV-AIDS and eradicate HIV transmission in the next decade. We will continue to to fight collectively against discrimination and health inequality to realise this ambition.

It was a pleasure to be asked by St John’s in Palmers Green to plant a tree on All Souls Day last weekend with the Mayor of Enfield in memory of all those who lost their lives to COVID-19 locally.
Thank you to Rev. Julie Coleman and all at St. John’s for this very fitting memorial.

You are here:Home1/News2/Supporting the 2022 Summer Reading Challenge
I was proud to support The Reading Agency’s Summer Reading Challenge with the Science Museum, which encourages children to participate in a reading adventure next month exploring science and innovation.

I enjoyed meeting the Brain Tumour Charity this week to support Brain Tumour Awareness Month, which was taking place throughout March.
Only 12% of adults diagnosed with a malignant brain tumour survive for five years or more. This needs to change and the Brain Tumour Charity do excellent work raising awareness and improving care and treatment for people diagnosed with brain tumours.

Children’s futures are being put at risk because this Government continues to ignore the rising demand for mental health services. Last year, 3 in 4 children referred to mental health services were not seen within four weeks.
I’m backing Labour’s plan to secure the future of mental health services, including:
– Treatment within a month and an end to agonising waiting lists for treatment
– Specialist mental health support in every school
– Open access mental health hubs in every community

I also enjoyed visiting the British Heart Foundation in Palmers Green to show my support for its Reuse Revolution and to meet staff and volunteers.
Locally, 6,900 people are living with heart and circulatory diseases, and every penny raised by the charity helps fund lifesaving research.

On Tuesday, I voted against the Government’s Health and Social Care Levy, which will raise National Insurance by 1.25% for working families and businesses. I believe this will place an enormous burden on hard working people in Enfield Southgate.
This is a tax rise that means a landlord renting out dozens of properties in Enfield wouldn’t pay a penny more, but their tenants working full time jobs would.
I believe those with the broadest shoulders should contribute more. Under a Labour government, we would actually tackle the social care crisis, rather than rush through a manifesto-breaking, unfair tax on jobs.

You are here:Home1/News2/Supporting Amnesty’s Write for Rights campaign
It was also a pleasure to join Amnesty’s reception in Parliament in support of its Write for Rights campaign. It is more important than ever we stand up for human rights around the world.

144 people have been executed in Saudi Arabia this year alone, a record high for the Kingdom and more than double the number last year.
A Minister recently told Parliament that Hussein Abo al-Kheir, a 57-year-old Jordanian man at risk of imminent execution in Saudi Arabia, had “clearly” been tortured.
However, he has since chosen to correct the record following this debate.
This is completely unacceptable and demonstrates the weakness of this Conservative government. I have called for the Foreign Office to come clean and urgently explain why the record has been corrected.

I was dismayed to learn of another licence application being made by a group called Palace Amusements for an Adult Gaming Centre at 369-371 Green Lanes, Palmers Green N13 4JH which are the former Lloyds Bank premises.
I will be submitting objections to the licence application and would also encourage local residents to take action.
Under the Gambling Act 2005 local authorities have limited capacity to decline applications and the objections that they can take into consideration are very narrow and specifically relate to:
“a) preventing gambling from being a source of crime or disorder, being associated with crime or disorder or being used to support crime;
b) ensuring that gambling is conducted in a fair and open way;
c) protecting children and other vulnerable persons from being harmed or exploited by gambling.”
The local authority can only accept as relevant representations those objections which contain evidence relating to the above grounds and any evidence submitted must be relevant to the specific area.
The Enfield Council Gambling Act 2005 – Gambling Local Area Profile (January 2022) contains data relating to the location of gambling premises can be found below.
The deadline for representations on this application is 30 July 2023.
Representations are to be made to Enfield Council at licensing@enfield.gov.uk
I understand that a planning application for a change of use will also have to be made, and I will update constituents as soon as I can.
It is extremely disappointing that despite the efforts of local community groups, such as Palmers Green Action Team, to improve the high street environment and create family friendly spaces, the growth in gambling premises is threatening this positive work.

I made representations to the Planning Committee to share my concerns on behalf of residents about the proposed development on Cockfosters Station Car Park, which I believe is an overdevelopment of the local area that will substantially change the green suburban character of Cockfosters.

Today, I spoke in support of Peter Lamb MP’s Free School Meals (Automatic Registration of Eligible Children) Bill.
Free school meals are a lifeline for low-income families and every child has the right to eat a nutritious meal to help them learn, achieve, & thrive at school.

Levelling up the UK cannot mean levelling down London, but locally all we’ve seen recently is the levelling down of financial support for Enfield.
Since 2010, consecutive Conservative governments have starved local authorities of sufficient resources and funding. Since 2018, central government has cut Enfield Council’s budget by £70.2million, while allocating nothing from the Town Fund, Levelling Up Fund and Community Renewal Fund.
I spoke to Enfield Dispatch about the raw deal Enfield is getting from government with neighbouring MPs Feryal Clark and Kate Osamor.

Endometriosis Action Month
To mark Endometriosis Action month, I met with representatives from Endometriosis UK, Anita Nneka Jones, and Charlotte Henshaw in Parliament. We had an important discussion around the impact endometriosis has on the daily life as well as physical and mental health.
It was great to hear more about how MPs can how support for women’s health.
If you, or someone you know, is struggling with issues relating to endometriosis, please contact Endometriosis UK’s nurse helpline.

I would like to thank constituents who have contacted me about amendments to the Environment Bill, which I know has caused concern for many in Enfield Southgate.
I voted to keep the Lords amendment to the Bill which would prevent private companies from being able to dump raw sewage into our rivers and waterways.
However, the Government voted for a weaker amendment on raw sewage which does not require water companies to take action quickly enough, allowing dumping to continue for years to come. It fails to give a specific number or target on sewage pollution.
We need stronger measures to end raw sewage discharges into our rivers and seas. The Conservatives are not moving quickly or being bold enough to tackle this disgusting practice.

It was brilliant to meet with students and teachers from Eversley Primary School twice in May.
Firstly, I welcomed pupils into Westminster for a great Q&A about politics, parliament and of course my role as an MP. It was wonderful to meet them all and they were an absolute credit to their school.
Then, I had the pleasure of visiting the school with the Shadow Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson. We met Year 5&6 pupils for a Q&A and had a very productive morning discussing the importance of education for the next Labour government with teachers.
Thank you to everyone from Eversley for organising these two visits!

I met with local campaigners who feel their voices are going unheard about the proposed development at Southgate Office Village. I’ve written to the Secretary of State to amplify their concerns and request that planning permission is revoked.

Temperatures hit extreme levels this week as the Met Office issued its first ever red weather warning for exceptional heat.
During the extreme weather, we saw the London Fire Brigade declare a major incident as several fires spread across the capital, including a fire locally on Green Lanes in Palmers Green which caused severe disruption and concern.
I would like to say a massive thank you to firefighters and the emergency services for their response to the fire in Green Lanes and for their incredible work to keep us all safe.

Hundreds of innocent people’s lives and livelihoods were ruined by the Post Office scandal. Among the victims were my constituents, Kamran Ashraf and Siema Kamran, who ran the Post Office in Hampstead Heath in the early 2000s.
I have written to the Business and Trade Minister Kevin Hollinrake MP this week on their behalf & on behalf of all the constituents who have contacted me recently about this important issue.

The news that Iran International TV has been forced to suspend its operations in London is incredibly worrying.
I pressed the Minister on the importance of press freedom and why the UK must ensure the safety of journalists who have played a vital role in reporting on the protests in Iran and the human rights abuses carried out by the regime.

Endometriosis Action Month
To mark Endometriosis Action month, I met with representatives from Endometriosis UK, Anita Nneka Jones, and Charlotte Henshaw in Parliament. We had an important discussion around the impact endometriosis has on the daily life as well as physical and mental health.
It was great to hear more about how MPs can how support for women’s health.
If you, or someone you know, is struggling with issues relating to endometriosis, please contact Endometriosis UK’s nurse helpline.

It was wonderful to welcome delegates from Commonwealth Parliaments, including Australia, Tanzania and the Falkland Islands, to Enfield Southgate in March with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.
The delegates visited me in my constituency office in Palmers Green to discuss the importance of casework and surgeries, before heading over to Enfield Council to meet councillors, the Council Leader and the Mayor of Enfield.

This week the Metropolitan Police issued fines for parties in Downing Street that broke lockdown rules. According to Boris Johnson, these parties never happened and he assured us that “all rules were followed.”
We now know the Prime Minister has lied repeatedly to the country and to the House of Commons, and his Government is failing people across the UK while taking us all for fools.

/in Enfield Southgate, News /by Bambos6th January 2021 –
Dentists across Enfield Southgate have contacted me about the issues they have been facing during the pandemic. They provide essential services that we all rely on and have worked hard to make their practices safe so they can continue to look after their patients.
I wrote to the Minster responsible for Dentistry, Jo Churchill MP, to raise these issues and aask how she will be working with NHS England to make sure our local dental practices, here in Enfield Southgate, don’t go bust.

You are here:Home1/News2/Meeting Send My Friend to School campaigners
It was wonderful to meet young ambassadors from the Send My Friend to School campaign during their Action Day in Parliament in June. I was inspired by their important campaign to ensure everyone around the world has access to education.

The Nationality and Borders Bill Committee has begun and as Shadow Immigration Minister, I will be scrutinising this fundamentally flawed and dangerous Bill line-by-line with MPs over the coming weeks.
We’ve heard from diverse witnesses during the evidence session of the Nationality and Borders Bill Committee, including from the British Red Cross, the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, local Councils and the National Crime Agency.
Home Office officials were originally planned to give evidence to the Committee but were removed from the witness list at the last minute – I raised this point, as it limits our ability to scrutinise those working in the Home Office on this legislation.
Rather than offering genuine proposals to fix the asylum system, this Bill aims to criminalise and punish many people seeking protection in this country. As the Afghan refugee crisis shows, we need to introduce safe and legal routes for those fleeing persecution abroad – not turn our backs on some of the most vulnerable people on Earth.
As the Committee continues to meet, I will be making these points clear to Ministers. I will also continue to work with colleagues to amend the Bill to properly meet the challenges of our broken asylum system.

Last Christmas, people were unable to say goodbye to dying loved ones. Meanwhile, Downing Street partied, laughed and lied about it.
I am deeply disgusted and angry. This Conservative Government and this Prime Minister are taking us all for fools, and I know many constituents share my anger. There is no doubt anymore that it’s one rule for them, and another rule for the rest of us.

We were promised integrity and professionalism from this Government. But this week we found out the Deputy Prime Minister is under investigation following complaints about his behaviour. For those keeping up, this comes after last week’s resignation by Gavin Williamson over accusations of bullying.
A new government maybe, but it’s the same old Tories.
At PMQs, which fell during anti-bullying week, I asked the Deputy PM if he’s ever entered into an NDA connected to a complaint against him.
You can view his rather carefully worded, yeah but no but, response below.

Last week, 81 men were executed in Saudi Arabia in the largest execution in its history. This week, the Prime Minister met the Crown Prince in Riyadh.
I spoke at the despatch box on Monday to call on our government to condemn this massacre in the strongest possible terms and ensure that human rights are at the fore of any trade deals with Saudi Arabia.

Protests in Iran have entered their ninth week. These protests, led by brave women and girls, are calling for an end to state violence and for ordinary Iranians to be able to live their lives as they choose.
There have also been horrific reports that detained protestors have been sentenced to death in Iran.
The UK must stand unequivocally against the death penalty, and we must also take steps to protect journalists and UK nationals critical of the Iranian regime.
You can view my response to an Urgent Question on protests in Iran below.
