Closing train station ticket offices – including all 5 in our constituency at Hadley Wood, Enfield Chase, Grange Park, Winchmore Hill and Palmers Green – will be devastating for passengers, jobs and safety.
I have written to the Secretary of State for Transport and Great Northern to share my concerns and I will be responding to the consultation in full.
I am opposed to these incredibly worrying plans as I strongly believe this will adversely impact elderly and disabled passengers, as well as ticket office staff and everyone who relies on the vital support and advice provided by staff in ticket offices.
You can read my letter to the Secretary of State for Transport below.
The closing date for the consultation is 26 July 2023.
Please join me in submitting your views, so we can show the government our strength of feeling against their ticket office closure plans.

It was fantastic to support Marie Curie’s Great Daffodil Appeal with Paul Chuckle this week. Marie Curie provide vital care and support to people living with a terminal illness and their loved, and they do incredible work in improving end of life care.

This week I voted to put an end to the tax breaks handed to private schools and to instead invest that money in state education, including recruiting thousands of new teachers and providing professional mental health support and careers guidance for every child.
The Conservatives voted against; it shows their priorities.

With interest rates rising to a 15-year high this week, households in Enfield Southgate are under more pressure than ever, with families facing average mortgage hikes of £6,600 this year.
This is a Tory mortgage penalty. Since their catastrophic mini-Budget, costs have skyrocketed and family finances are being devastated.
Support is needed, but we can’t trust the Tories to provide it.
The Prime Minister was warned by experts about this in the autumn. But his Government has been too consumed by its own law-breaking, its own chaos and the never-ending Tory psychodrama to care.
We need practical measures to tackle this crisis, including requiring lenders to allow mortgage holders to temporarily switch to interest-only mortgage payments and to lengthen the term of their mortgage period. And requiring lenders to wait a minimum of six months before initiating repossession proceedings, because we’re seeing a 50% rise in repossessions already as a result of this crisis.

The Conservatives held a vote of confidence in Boris Johnson, and while the Prime Minister won the vote, 148 of his own MPs voted against him. This is a terrible result and shows he has effectively lost the confidence of his backbenchers.
It’s a worse result than Thatcher in 1990; worse than May in 2018; and worse than Major in 1995.
Boris Johnson is a dead man walking, but the Conservatives have chosen to ignore the British public and hitched themselves and their party firmly to him and all he represents. They have no plan to tackle the issues we are facing in this country, and I believe the Government will continue to lurch from one scandal to another under his leadership.

The cost of living crisis isn’t over and people in our community are still struggling to make ends meet. That’s why I believe we needed a long-term plan from the Government in last week’s Budget.
Instead, we got more of the same from a tired Tory government with the wrong priorities: Opportunities missed and working people paying the price for 13 years of economic failure. I voted against the Tory tax break for the richest 1%, which is clearly the wrong priority during a cost of living crisis.

The NHS is in crisis. This is not down to NHS staff, who continue to go above and beyond to protect people. The problems we’re facing today are the consequence of more than a decade of Conservative mismanagement.
Patients are waiting longer than ever and staff are completely overworked. And with our health service on its knees, Ministers are nowhere to be seen. It’s a disgrace and we urgently need the Government to get a grip.
As your MP, I’ve been calling for a long-term plan to fix the NHS so that patients in our community are seen on time and local NHS staff are properly supported. This starts with investing in our NHS workforce, recruiting more staff and giving our health service the support it needs.

It was UK Parliament Week recently, an event that engages and empowers young people to participate in our democracy.
To support this important event, I visited De Bohun primary school for a Q&A with years 2,3 and 4. Thank you to pupils for their excellent questions and to everyone at the school for organising the visit.

I enjoyed a fantastic visit to Specsavers in Palmers Green to mark World Hearing Day and get my hearing tested too. It’s alarming to know that by 2035, 14.6 million UK adults are projected to have age-related hearing loss.
It’s time to prioritise our hearing health and a huge thank you to the Specsavers team for their time.

19 October was National Thalassaemia Day, and it was an important opportunity to raise awareness and support those affected by this blood disorder that disrupts haemoglobin production.
Individuals with Thalassaemia have minimal or no haemoglobin, crucial for oxygen transport by red blood cells. Treatment can be intensive and involves regular blood transfusions.
Our community in Southgate has the highest number of people with thalassaemia in the country.
I was delighted to join London Greek Radio to discuss thalassaemia in my role as chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for Thalassaemia.
You can show your support for people with thalassaemia by learning more about the condition and following the UK Thalassaemia Society’s incredible work below.

3,450 people in Enfield are living with dementia and it is vital they get the support they need.
In November, I visited Age UK Enfield’s dementia day centre, where residents with dementia receive high quality care and take part in a range of activities to stimulate the memory and mind. Thank you to Venetta and the team for your incredible work supporting people across the borough who are living with dementia.
With new research showing that 1.7 million people in England and Wales could be living with dementia by 2040, we have to ensure that everyone living with dementia gets the diagnosis, support, and hopefully soon, the treatment they need.
Back in July, I wrote to the Health Secretary to urge him to prioritise dementia. You can view my letter below.

Hospices care for people at their most vulnerable, providing essential care and support at the end of life. But right now, soaring energy costs are threatening these vital services. For North London Hospice, which operates in our community, keeping patients warm and running essential equipment now costs almost £450,000, up from just £133,000 the previous year.
As a community, we are reliant on hospices and the incredible services they provide. But they are reliant on us for support too – with charitable donations making up around 70-80% of their income. Therefore, as the cost of living crisis hits us all, it is becoming increasingly difficult for hospices to raise funds and keep their services going.
To help meet these challenges, North London Hospice has launched its summer appeal: Fund Our Nurses Month for August.

An issue that is impacting the lives of many local residents is the Home Office’s failure to deal with well-publicised backlogs, and I am receiving an increasing volume of casework relating to the Home Office – from delays in the Passport Office, the asylum system, visa extensions, citizenship applications and the Ukrainian visa schemes. Sadly, I expect this to continue over the coming weeks.
The Passport Office now has a 10-week target to process applications and many people looking forward to a long-awaited holiday are now facing an anxious wait for a passport, often applied for months ago.
The Government should be clear with people whether the situation is going to get worse before it gets better and take urgent action to address organisational failings.

I had the pleasure of joining the Fabian Society New Year Conference in January, where I spoke on managing migration, highlighting how the Conservative Government’s policies are failing business and the country and why we need a fair, humane and efficient system.
I joined the Jewish Labour Movement’s conference to speak on Labour’s Middle East policy as Shadow Middle East Minister. It was great to see so many friends from across the party at the conference.

A 22-year-old woman, Mahsa Amini, was arrested in Iran for allegedly breaking strict hijab rules. She tragically died three days later following injuries suffered in police custody.
As the Shadow Middle East Minister, I’ve written to the FCDO urging the UK to call for an impartial investigation into her death and condemn worrying human rights escalations in Iran, including the discrimination of women and girls by the regime’s morality police, attacks on protestors, and the persecution of LGBTQ+ people.

Many people have contacted me about The Hunting Trophies (Import Prohibition) Bill.
This Private Member’s Bill has my full support and I was in Parliament to see it pass through its Commons stages without needing a vote.
I am delighted the Government, the Opposition and MPs from across the House have supported this important campaign and the work of Ban Trophy Hunting, FOUR PAWS and other groups.
We need to end the barbaric practice of trophy hunting, which is incredibly cruel, pushes endangered wildlife closer to extinction and brings unnecessary suffering to animals.

From 1 April, household energy bills will be the highest on record.
Last week’s Spring Statement did little to help people in our community with the cost of living. Under the Tories, families across the UK are £2,620 worse off.
As we head into the local elections in May here in Enfield, it’s clear that people can no longer afford a Conservative government. In contrast, Labour has a plan to step up and help families through the cost of living crisis by introducing a windfall tax on oil and gas companies in the North Sea.

It was great to be at London Labour’s election campaign launch in Barnet today with Keir Starmer, Sadiq Khan and MPs and councillors from across London ahead of the local elections in May.
As the cost of living soars, these elections are a chance to send the Conservative Government a clear message. Vote Labour on 5th May for a party that is on your side.
I was also out on the doorstep in Palmers Green over the weekend, and it was wonderful to speak to many constituents who shared their strong support for our local Labour team.

It was important to join Diabetes UK in Parliament recently to discuss how we can improve care and better support the 5 million people living with diabetes in the UK.
For everyone with diabetes, the right support is essential to help prevent life-changing complications, but far too many are missing out on vital checks.

Stem Cell Meeting
It was wonderful to meet my constituent Michael Efstratiou’s uncle and daughter, Costas and Ellianna, today in Parliament as they continue their tireless campaign to find a stem cell match for Michael.
Before Christmas, Michael was sadly diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer and urgently needs a stem cell transplant. Due to his Cypriot heritage, it is proving difficult to find a match for Michael.
He needs people to sign up to the stem cell register, in the hope that they could be a match for someone just like him.
Aged 16-30? Sign up to the register today @ https://www.anthonynolan.org/…/michaelsstemcelldrive

In early March, I met with Nationwide to discuss the planned closures of branches in Southgate and Palmers Green. I am very concerned about the impact of these closures on residents, particularly local businesses and older people. As we recover from the pandemic, it is crucial that residents are able to access cash and financial services continue to serve everyone in the community.
If you have concerns about these branch closures please do not hesitate to get in touch with me at bambos.charalambous.mp@parliament.uk

Yesterday, I attended the groundbreaking ceremony of Haringey Civic Centre’s restoration.
Marking the redevelopment of the civic centre is an exciting step towards improving the sustainability of Haringey Council’s offices and access to residents and visitors to ready the building for the future. The redevelopment will ensure the Civic Centre reopens with a larger footprint to serve residents as a hub for Council services and offer public cultural spaces.
It is also wonderful to see how the Council have used the online consultation, Civic Voices, to engage with local residents and use their views to design this new and improved Civic Centre, while preserving history and celebrating important memories.

It was great to visit My Dental Care in Bounds Green on Friday to meet dentist Mark Marcou to discuss issues accessing NHS dentistry in Southgate and Wood Green and challenges facing NHS practice owners.
I am pleased that the Government is committed to saving NHS dentistry and ensuring everyone who needs access, can get it.
https://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/edac97fb-877a-4fd9-9cbe-74807b4e1b13-1.jpeg15362048Bamboshttps://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/BC-Logo.svgBambos2025-04-28 10:38:152025-04-28 10:38:15Visit to My Dental Care
It was wonderful to open Aaron Gayle Court in Wood Green today with Joanne McCartney AM, Leader Cllr Peray Ahmet, Deputy Leader Cllr Sarah Williams, and the Deputy Mayor for Housing Tom Copley.
With 23 new homes for Haringey, Aaron Gayle is part of Haringey Council’s programme to deliver 3000 new council homes by 2031.
It was wonderful to visit the staff and residents of Five Oaks Care Home today in Cockfosters.
Thank you to everyone for all your hard work in making the care home run so smoothly and for the wonderful spread!
https://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/GoQtZLiXEAA5YqH.jpg675900Bamboshttps://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/BC-Logo.svgBambos2025-04-14 08:54:412025-04-14 08:55:10Visit to Five Oaks Care Home
Today, I spoke up for our local Enfield and Haringey Councils in the Local Government Finances in London Westminster Hall debate.
Enfield and Haringey deserve the right funding to provide good services for residents, and both councils have seen severe declines in their funding since 2010. Damping council funds is wrong – the inner-outer London formula is unfair and must be scrapped.

I had a lovely visit to St Michael at Bowes Primary School yesterday to meet the school council. We had an important discussion on bullying and the impact it has on children.
It was great to hear what they like about school and their favourite lessons, and discuss a visit for the council to come to Parliament!
https://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/IMG_1954-scaled.jpeg19202560Bamboshttps://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/BC-Logo.svgBambos2025-03-18 16:45:372025-03-18 16:45:38Visit to St Michael at Bowes
I welcomed the Southgate and Wood Green Women’s Constituency Labour Party to Parliament to have a serious discussion about tackling violence against women and girls in today’s society as we marked International Women’s Day last week. We spoke about the resources local authorities can use to help victims of domestic abuse and the severe impact social media has on cultivating misogynist attitudes among teenage boys and young men. We also discussed the role of the UK Government in supporting women in conflict zones internationally. We took a tour of Parliament where we saw pieces of suffragette history, including the cupboard where Emily Wilding Davison hid in on the night of the 1911 census!
This discussion served as a powerful reminder that there is still a long way to go in creating a safer society for women and girls. Currently there is a worrying level of sexual violence, domestic abuse and harassment experienced by women daily in the UK. By the end of 2023, there were only 2008 convictions for the 67,938 rape offences recorded by the police and data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has shown that almost a quarter of women aged 16-24 experienced sexual harassment last year.
Beyond these numbers are survivors whose lives have not only been deeply harmed by the abuse they have experienced, but also the failing systems they have turned to for support. It is imperative that the Government views the safety of women and girls as an utmost priority over this parliament, so we can strive towards a society where women are empowered rather than inhibited.

Sunday the 9th of March marked Covid Reflection Day, a time to remember the lives lost during the pandemic. I would like to pay tribute to the sacrifices made by our community and brave frontline workers in Southgate and Wood Green.
Marking the fifth anniversary of the pandemic, I paid a visit to the Covid Memorial Wall earlier this week, where families honour their loved ones and the 247,458 people who died from coronavirus.

Yesterday, I met with Year 9 students and school councillors at Mulberry Academy Woodside.
We had a productive Q&A, discussing a variety of topics. I was asked for my advice for young people, what parliament does, and to explain a typical day at work for me.
It was wonderful to meet so many young people keen to engage with and learn about politics. I hope to come back soon!

As the single biggest indicator of a child’s future success, reading for fun matters. It gives children a sense of agency, choice, and empowerment.
Well done to all the parents, carers, librarians, and teachers helping children in Southgate and Wood Green pick up a book & discover reading in their own way!
https://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/DSC_5371ed-scaled.jpg25601844Bamboshttps://www.bambos.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/BC-Logo.svgBambos2025-03-06 11:14:122025-03-06 11:23:54World Book Day 2025!

Christmas is coming and while it’s been another challenging year, I hope everyone in our community is able to enjoy the festive season.
I recently did the countdown for the Christmas tree lights in Palmers Green alongside friends, colleagues, and pupils from Hazelwood Primary School. It was great to see so many familiar faces in attendance and a big thank you to Green Lanes Business Association for organising the event and for bringing the festive spirit to Palmers Green.

Inflation has risen to 9%, the highest in 40 years, and the Conservative Government is still failing to protect people from the cost of living crisis as prices soar and oil and gas companies rake in record profits.
I voted for a windfall tax on oil and gas producers to cut household bills and an Emergency Budget to tackle the cost of living crisis now. Conservative MPs voted against these measures as the Government continues to sit on its hands.

I enjoyed speaking at Migrants4Labour’s reception for migrant Labour candidates, alongside Labour’s General Secretary David Evans, and Lord Alf Dubs.
It was great to hear from so many outstanding candidates standing for Labour and I wish them them all the best of luck.

As the first elected MP of wholly Cypriot heritage, I always try to be a powerful advocate for Cyprus whenever I can. That’s why I have raised concerns with the FCDO about freedom to worship in the northern part of Cyprus.
Orthodox Christian and Maronite communities face restrictions when practicing their faith in the region, with some religious sites impossible to access, services interrupted or prohibited altogether, and requests for services denied.

On Monday, the Northern Ireland Protocol Bill – which breaks international law and risks the integrity of the Good Friday Agreement – passed Second Reading. However, more than 70 Tory MPs abstained and it’s clear that this proposal will also divide the Conservative Party while it divides the UK and Europe.
With this Bill, Boris Johnson is taking a wrecking ball to the deal he negotiated, signed and campaigned on. Once again, the PM is damaging Britain’s hard-won reputation as a dependable country that plays by the rules.
That’s why I voted against the Bill and will continue to call for the UK to negotiate with all parties and sort this out as quickly as possible.

I had the pleasure of visiting Atkinsons Chemists in Winchmore Hill with the National Pharmacy Association. As a busy local pharmacy, the team provide a range of services and support for our local community, and it was important to hear about their challenges during and after the pandemic.
Always good to get the blood pressure taken too.

I was proud to secure a debate in Parliament to raise awareness about thalassaemia – a genetic blood disorder that affects many people in the UK, including here in Enfield Southgate which has the highest number of people with thalassaemia in the country.
In the UK, thalassaemia services are under resourced, underdeveloped, and understaffed. Patients have also reported that they feel their ethnicity is linked to below standard treatment and in some cases racism.
As Chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Thalassaemia, I’m calling on the Government to raise awareness of thalassaemia among health professionals and the wider public to improve health outcomes for people with the condition.

The Tories have crashed the economy and are now threatening to make pensioners pay the price by breaking the triple lock.
The last 12 years of the Conservatives have left us with a weak economy and a cost-of-living crisis – and after September’s mini budget, the Tories are now being forced to consider massive spending cuts and breaking the triple lock on state pensions.
It is not fair that pensioners should be forced to pay the price for Tory mismanagement of the economy.
I voted – alongside Labour colleagues – to protect pensioners who have worked hard all their lives and deserve financial security and dignity in retirement. Conservative MPs, on the other hand, abstained.

I was very disappointed by the planning inspector’s decision to allow the appeal against the council’s refusal of permission for a development at Arnos Grove Underground station car park.
Last year I lodged objections to the proposal after many conversations with constituents. The strength of feeling was clear then and I continue to share these concerns today.
You can read my thoughts about the development in Enfield Dispatch below.

Presentation of a Petition
Today, I presented a petition to the House on behalf of my constituent, Jane Wessman, to call for free RSV and Shingles vaccines to be extended for those over the age of 80.
Today, I presented a petition to the House on behalf of my constituent, Jane Wessman, to call for free RSV and Shingles vaccines to be extended for those over the age of 80.
As the global debt crises cripples the Global South, I secured a debate on debt cancellation for low income countries. It was great to see so many other MPs show support for this cause and contribute to a productive afternoon in Westminster Hall.
I asked the Govt to support my Debt Relief (Developing Countries) Bill which would:
– compel private creditors to accept the same terms as other lenders
– reduce debt burden for the poorest countries
– cost the Treasury absolutely nothing
Spending more on debt servicing than on health or education cannot continue. The UK must act now.
The Second Reading of my Bill is due to be the 14th March 2025.
Low-income Countries: Debt Cancellation – Hansard – UK Parliament
I had a lovely visit to Our Lady of Lourdes on Friday to meet their school council! We spoke about the similarities in how we were both elected, how children can support their community and what issues matter most to them.
It was great to hear about the positive changes they have made to their school already – introducing reading buddies, improving their facilities, fundraising, and starting a calm club.
Well done to all the school councillors at Our Lady of Lourdes!
It was wonderful to meet my constituent Michael Efstratiou’s uncle and daughter, Costas and Ellianna, today in Parliament as they continue their tireless campaign to find a stem cell match for Michael.
Before Christmas, Michael was sadly diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer and urgently needs a stem cell transplant. Due to his Cypriot heritage, it is proving difficult to find a match for Michael.
He needs people to sign up to the stem cell register, in the hope that they could be a match for someone just like him.
Aged 16-30? Sign up to the register today @ https://www.anthonynolan.org/…/michaelsstemcelldrive

I had the delight of welcoming my constituent Michaela, her sister Chloe and her parents to Westminster during October half term.
In March, I received a note from 7-year-old Michaela inviting me to tea based on the Tiger who came to tea book. It was wonderful to enjoy that long-awaited tea in Parliament, where we discussed her ideas for her school parliament.
I think we have two future MPs in the making!

The Tories have gone from clapping nurses to sacking them. I voted against their plans to restrict the right to strike.
The Strikes (Minimum Service Levels) Bill isn’t about public safety, it’s a fundamental attack on workers’ rights that will do nothing to prevent strikes or resolve disputes.

Transport Questions
I asked the Minister for the Future of Roads, Lillian Greenwood, what steps the Government were taking to protect two-wheeling couriers in the gig economy. These riders are at a higher risk of road danger than the average rider, due to time pressures from employers.
You can listen to her response here:

Cancer waiting times were the worst on record last year, according to Macmillan Cancer Support.
I raised this shocking statistic in the House of Commons. After 13 years of Conservative failure, our NHS does not have the staff it needs and patients are paying the price. We need to tackle this crisis by urgently investing in the NHS workforce.

I am pleased to support a campaign, led by Palmers Green Action Team, to bring an independent cinema to our local community.
I believe it will be a unique local space for Palmers Green and will help to rejuvenate our high street after a difficult few years during the pandemic.

Privacy Policy
Last updated 19 March 2024
As the MP for Southgate and Wood Green, my staff and I keep in touch with constituents about my work, to take up casework on their behalf and to ask for views on local issues.
This Privacy Notice explains how I will collect and use personal data, the legal basis for doing so and provides information about your rights in respect of your personal data. As holder of that data I am called the Data Controller.
I manage your data in line with responsibilities under the UK General Data Protection Regulation (UK GDPR), as supplemented by the Data Protection Act 2018.
As the Data Controller, I can be contacted on bambos.charalambous.mp@parliament.uk or by writing to Bambos Charalambous MP, 472 Green Lanes, Palmers Green, London N13 5PA.
Data collection and use
The office of Bambos Charalambous MP will only collect and use personal information for the specific purpose for which it has been obtained.
Policy enquiries and casework (personal problems) enquiries bring with them information provided by a constituent and/or on behalf of a constituent.
It may be necessary for my office to share your information with third party organisations. This will only be shared when it is necessary and reasonable to do so. My office will share only the minimum amount of personal information necessary to ensure that an enquiry is handled efficiently or to advocate on your behalf.
Please see the “who I share your information with” section for further details.
How we collect your personal data
Where you provide personal information, it will only be used for the services you requested.
My office will collect your personal data when you:
- contact the office with an enquiry or about a campaign.
- respond to surveys, questionnaires, or evaluations.
- participate in a surgery.
- agree to receive communications such as newsletters or social media subscriptions.
- submit information to register for an event.
When registering with this website or by completing a form or survey sent to you by my office, you may be asked for personal information. In each case, I will ask for your explicit consent to use your information, and I will only use it for the purposes for which you provide it.
I may communicate by post, email, phone, or text message about my work and to give you the latest news on my campaigns and opportunities to get involved. I have a legal entitlement to the full electoral register for my constituency, which includes the full name and address of every registered elector, and I may write to you in connection with my activities as an MP.
I will only send emails, texts or contact you by telephone where you have provided explicit consent for me to do so. You may withdraw your consent or unsubscribe at any time from communications in any medium by contacting me as the Data Controller or by using the unsubscribe option I provide in all communications.
I will not use personal data for any automated decision making or profiling.
Who I will share your information with:
When I take up casework on your behalf, it may be necessary for me to share the details you provide with government departments, local authorities, and other public bodies. I will only share as much information as is necessary to take your case forward. If you have any questions or concerns about how information you provide as part of a casework request is used, please contact me as the Data Controller for more information.
Other than in the circumstances above, I will not share personal information with other organisations without your explicit consent.
To communicate with you about my work as the MP for the Enfield Southgate constituency, it may be necessary for me to transfer personal information to countries or jurisdictions outside the EU. In each case, I will take steps to ensure that the suppliers used comply with the General Data Protection Regulation or are subject to the Privacy Shield scheme agreed between the European Union and the United States.
For further information see: UK Parliament website privacy notice – UK Parliament
How long do we keep your data for?
I will only keep your personal data for as long as is necessary for the purpose it was collected and to fulfil the purposes described in this policy. All personal data is collected on a secure electronic system. Any paper documents supplied to me are scanned onto the electronic system in the data subject’s file and securely destroyed or returned to the ‘data subject’ in the post, if return has been requested. There are no paper records kept in my office. You are advised to retain your own copies of correspondence, should you wish to keep a record of your case.
I may retain information about closed cases if you contact me again for help. I may delete information that I consider repetitive to hold minimal personal data. Personal data will be disposed of securely.
Cases will be kept for a maximum of two years after the last meaningful contact between my office and a constituent. Cases will only be kept beyond two years if I have reason to keep the file or if the constituent has asked that case is retained.
If you have consented to receive information about my work, I will only retain your personal information so long as I am the MP for the Enfield Southgate constituency, or you ask not to be contacted further.
I will regularly review the personal information I hold to ensure that its use is necessary and proportionate.
Website and social media policy
IP Address and Cookies
My website does not automatically capture or store personal information, other than logging the user’s IP Address or the location of your computer or network on the Internet, for systems administration and troubleshooting purposes. I will also use IP addresses in the aggregate to track which pages people visit in order to improve the quality of the site.
A cookie is a tiny text file that is stored on your computer. Cookies may be used to tailor your experience on this site according to the preferences you have specified. Cookies on this website do not contain personally identifiable information, other than your IP address, which itself is only very rarely enough to identify you as an individual.
Links to other websites
This website contains links to other websites. Bambos Charalambous MP is not responsible for the content or privacy practices of these websites.
Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.
Social Media Platforms
Communication, engagement, and actions taken through external social media platforms that this office, website and its owners participate on are custom to the terms and conditions as well as the privacy policies held with each social media platform respectively.
Users are advised to use social media platforms wisely and communicate / engage upon them with due care and caution regarding their own privacy and personal details. I will not ask for personal or sensitive information through social media platforms and encourage users wishing to discuss personal matters to use primary communication channels such as by email or telephone.
This website may use social sharing buttons which help share web content directly from web pages to the social media platform in question. Users are advised before using such social sharing buttons that they do so at their own discretion and note that the social media platform may track and save your request to share a web page respectively through your social media platform account. Pixel codes are used to promote my work from this website onto social media platforms.
Your rights
You have several rights in relation to your personal information and the opportunity to choose how it is used. You can:
- Obtain copies of the personal information I hold about you (known as a “subject access request”).
- Request that I correct or update any personal information held about you.
- Ask that we delete or restrict the way in which I use your information.
- Request that personal information you have given your consent for me to use is provided in an electronic format so it can be transferred to another data controller (also known as “data portability”).
If you wish to exercise your rights in respect of your personal data or have any concerns about how your data is used, please contact the data controller Bambos Charalambous MP:
Contact details of the Data Controller
Bambos Charalambous MP
House of Commons
London
SW1A 0AA
Email: bambos.charalambous.mp@parliament.uk
Telephone: 0207 219 3460
You have right to raise any issues or concerns directly with the Information Commissioner’s Office.
Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO)
Contact Bambos Charalambous MP
Website: www.bambos.org.uk
Email: bambos.charalambous.mp@parliament.uk
Telephone: 0207 219 3460
Changes to this notice
We may update this privacy notice from time to time In that case the ‘last updated’ date at the top of this page will also change. Any changes to this privacy notice will apply to you and your data immediately.
Version 3.0 Updated 19 March 2024

I spoke in a Westminster Hall debate to mark UN International Day of Education.
With 222 million children around the word affected by emergency and protracted crises, and in need of urgent educational support, tackling the challenge we face in global education has never been more important.
Ahead of the debate, I had the pleasure of meeting with the Global Partnership for Education youth leaders in Parliament. It was important to show my support for protecting and increasing education funding worldwide and hear directly from these young people about how multiple crises are disrupting education on an unprecedented scale.
Education is a human right, but from Afghanistan to Ukraine, there are millions of children around the world in need of urgent educational support. I called on the Government to turn rhetoric into results and act for children in emergencies before we fail a generation of young people.

My first event at conference was Bond and Labour Foreign Policy Group’s panel event on foreign policy and development with Preet Gill MP, where we discussed the crucial role of aid in foreign policy.
I’ve seen first hand the terrible impact of Tory cuts to aid while in Lebanon, where mine clearances are under threat due to the Government’s decision to cut funding for humanitarian mine action by 80%.
Cuts to aid send the message to places like South Sudan, Myanmar, Iraq and elsewhere that the UK no longer cares and is no longer a world leader in foreign affairs.
That’s why development will be at the heart of the next Labour government’s vision to foster peace and stability across the world, and I was proud to make this clear during the event.

Macmillan Coffee Morning is always a wonderful event each year.
I was delighted to join Macmillan volunteers fundraising in Enfield Town Market Place with their coffee and cake event. Well done to Hayes Rees, Cllr Gina Needs and all the volunteers who made the fundraising event such a success.

In Parliament, I have been leading the Opposition’s scrutiny of the Nationality and Borders Bill as Shadow Immigration Minister. We are challenging the Bill ‘line-by-line’ over the next few weeks.
This week’s sessions included rectifying historical injustices in UK law for British Overseas Territory Citizens. We welcomed these measures.
However, we also discussed more controversial measures, like the creation of a two-tiered system for refugees, which judges vulnerable people based on how they arrived here in the UK, not on their needs.
Labour is strongly opposed to this and I made my views clear to Ministers this week, as I believe the Government is dehumanising refugees. In practice, the two-tiered system would see refugees who have fled Afghanistan through third countries being penalised and later criminalised. It is victim blaming of the most crass and immoral type.
On Wednesday, I was proud to join the Refugees Welcome rally outside Parliament to voice my concerns with the Bill.

Many people have contacted me about the UK’s response to the refugee and humanitarian crisis in Ukraine. I share the anger felt by many. The Home Office’s chaotic response has badly let down desperate Ukrainian people in their hour of need.
Families fleeing conflict in Ukraine need urgent help right now to reach safety and get support, and Labour is calling for a quick, simple and safe route to sanctuary for all who need it.
I was also pleased to join the Red Cross and The Voices Network in Parliament to hear from those with first hand experience of our asylum system and reaffirm my commitment to supporting refugee and asylum seekers’ rights.

The Wakefield by-election later this month is an important opportunity to send the Government a clear message. That’s why it was great to be out in Wakefield campaigning for our brilliant Labour candidate Simon Lightwood.
We found strong support for Labour on the doorstep, with lots of people fed up with the divided Conservatives and their rule-breaking Prime Minister.

Ahead of the Autumn Statement, many constituents contacted me about rising homelessness and the cost of living, and local housing allowance (LHA).
LHA has been frozen since 2020. While other benefits have been uprated in line with inflation, LHA has remained at the same level as it was 3 years ago – which is based on rents in the year up to September 2019. Since then, bills and the cost of living have increased significantly, with rents rising at the fastest rate on record.
LHA is a critical element of people’s income and many are now being forced to make up the difference between their rent and LHA. Many have already, and will continue, to reduce their spending on other necessities such as food and heating or risk getting into rent arrears, which puts them in danger of becoming homeless.
This is causing hardship for people in our community, and it is something that comes up in my casework day in, day out.
I wrote to the Chancellor about this issue urging him to consider taking steps to support people in our community by increasing LHA in line with inflation.
I was pleased and relieved that the Chancellor listened to these calls.
It is not all good news though. The uplift in LHA will not be implemented until April 2024, which means people in our community will face another uncertain and difficult winter with the cost of living and rent.

Every 36 seconds someone will die from hunger in East Africa.
In Parliament, I joined Oxfam, the Red Cross and Action Against Hunger to show my support for some of the most vulnerable people in the world. It’s time the UK stepped up and showed leadership before it’s too late.

The UK should unequivocally condemn the recent executions in Saudi Arabia and the use of the death penalty.
In the last two weeks, executions have been taking place on almost a daily basis in Saudi Arabia – 144 people have been executed in the Kingdom this year alone, a record high.
We must use our close relationship to press for a change in approach in Saudi Arabia, calling for an end to executions and the release of Hussein Abo al-Kheir.

The Home Office’s first flight as part of proposals to offshore asylum seekers in Rwanda was cancelled.
The Government can’t blame anyone but themselves, and it is incredibly misleading for the Prime Minister to suggest lawyers who bring legal challenges against the Government are doing anything other than upholding the rule of law.
I believe the Rwanda asylum scheme is cruel, extortionately expensive, and risks making dangerous people trafficking worse. By chasing headlines, Boris Johnson is abandoning British values and pursuing an unworkable plan while failing to improve asylum decision making or crack down on criminal gangs.

I was shocked to learn from reports in the Independent that Home Office Ministers wasted millions of taxpayers’ money on a ‘prison-style’ asylum camp that was never used.
As Shadow Immigration Minister, I spoke to the Independent about this latest example of Home Office incompetence under the Conservatives. I believe this is just one of many examples of the government’s incompetent, wasteful and uncaring asylum policy.

On Wednesday, Labour called on the Government to cancel the cut to Universal Credit in Parliament.
This £20 is what enables some families to put food on the table at the end of the week, and if the cut goes ahead, it would be devastating for millions already struggling to get by, leave unemployment support at a 30-year low in the midst of a jobs crisis and threaten our economic recovery.
With my Labour colleagues, I voted to cancel the cut and keep the £20 Universal Credit lifeline.
Meanwhile, preoccupied with a reshuffle, the Conservatives shamefully abstained on the vote. It highlights once again that this Government simply doesn’t understand the realities of working people’s lives.

I spoke to the Today Programme about my constituent Dilnaz Kerim’s campaign to locate her family in Xinjiang.
The Chinese Government claims that her Uyhgur family do not exist and continue to deny any wrongdoing. I’ve been helping Dilnaz by campaigning with the Foreign Office and Chinese Embassy to find out if they are safe.

I was proud to speak in a Westminster Hall debate on ADHD and autism assessments.
One in 20 people in the UK reportedly have ADHD. And while awareness has increased and a lot more people – especially women – are openly talking about ADHD and seeking a diagnosis, there remain severe delays and barriers to diagnosis and treatment for ADHD in the UK today.
As the Chair of the APPG for ADHD, I urged the Government to act now to improve ADHD treatment and diagnosis so we can start to break down the barriers to success that people across the country continue to face in their everyday lives.

On 20 July I wound up the debate for the 2nd reading of the Nationality & Borders Bill. This #AntiRefugeeBill is a draconian and dog whistling piece of legislation which will criminalise refugees according to how they arrive in the UK. This contravenes the Refugee Convention which has its 70th anniversary this month. As I said in my speech, the Bill is like the Queen of Hearts – sentencing people first and checking their claim to sanctuary later. It does nothing to provide safe routes for refugees and penalises those fleeing war and persecution.

Visit to My Dental Care
It was great to visit My Dental Care in Bounds Green on Friday to meet dentist Mark Marcou to discuss issues accessing NHS dentistry in Southgate and Wood Green and challenges facing NHS practice owners.
I am pleased that the Government is committed to saving NHS dentistry and ensuring everyone who needs access, can get it.

Meeting with Larry Lamb and Marie Curie
This week, as part of the Great Daffodil Appeal, I met with nurses and volunteers from Marie Curie, along with their supporter, Larry Lamb, in Parliament.
It was important to discuss palliative and end of life care, focusing on how MPs can show support to the sector, as I continue to call for increased funding for hospices.
It was great to talk to them, and I am proud to support Marie Curie and the incredible service they give to people at the end of life.

North Mid Sickle Cell and Thalassemia Centre
On New Years Eve, I joined the Chief Nurse for London, Karen Bonner MBE, to officially open the sickle cell and thalassemia emergency department bypass unit at North Middlesex University Hospital.
I want to thank those who played a huge role in making this bypass unit possible, improving care and securing better outcomes for patients who present to the emergency department with sickle cell disease and thalassemia.

This week the Boundary Commission published its latest proposals for Westminster constituencies ahead of the next general election.
Under the latest proposals, my constituency of Enfield Southgate will change to Southgate and Wood Green constituency, which you can see in full below.
The proposals will see Enfield Southgate lose Winchmore Hill and the new Highfield ward to Edmonton constituency, and Grange Park to Enfield North constituency.
I will be sad to lose these wards, having built very strong relationships and friendships with schools, businesses and residents in these areas.
Southgate and Wood Green will be joined with Bounds Green, Noel Park, White Hart Lane and Woodside wards in Haringey. I look forward to welcoming residents from these areas to my constituency should the plans be finalised.
This proposal is different from the initial plan, outlined in 2021, to merge Enfield Southgate with parts of Barnet. However, this proposal is now the final consultation on the revised boundaries.
The consultation is open until 5th December. More information about the latest proposals and the consultation can be found on the Boundary Commission website.

It was fantastic to join the Mental Health Foundation to raise awareness about this year’s Mental Health Awareness Week theme of loneliness.
Loneliness affects the mental health of millions, but many of us still find it hard to talk about. Let’s tackle loneliness together by reaching out to friends and loved ones. It can make a huge difference.

Before conference got underway, Saturday’s surgery at Eversley Primary School was a great success and a big thank you to my excellent casework team and everyone who booked an appointment.
We have regular constituency advice surgeries at Eversley Primary School and Chickenshed Theatre, as well as fortnightly telephone surgeries, but please note surgery appointments must be pre-booked and are on a first come first served basis.

As children went back to school, the full extent of the Government’s incompetence on RAAC has come to light, and I know people are understandably anxious about this situation.
It is unacceptable that parents have been in the dark about the dangers posed to their children at school and what buildings contain reinforced autoclaved aerated concrete (RAAC).
Local update
As information finally comes out about what schools are affected, we know there are three schools in Enfield impacted. However, none have had to close and all schools in the borough were able to open for the return of the academic year as normal.
In our constituency, I understand that Winchmore School has identified RAAC in a small part of the school, and this area has been sealed off with no danger to staff and pupils. I will continue to update constituents as the situation develops, including with more information about other public buildings that may be affected.
In other parts of England, the identification of RAAC has caused massive disruption and anxiety for pupils, teachers and parents, with some schools forced to close.
Rishi Sunak’s responsibility in this crisis
Back when he was Chancellor, Rishi Sunak was warned about the state of school buildings and the need to properly fund a school rebuilding programme.
He was reportedly presented evidence by Department for Education officials that there was a ‘critical risk to life’ and that these problems needed urgent action; it was recommended that funding was needed to rebuild 300 to 400 schools a year in England. Rishi Sunak ignored this advice, providing initial funding for 100 schools, which was then halved again to only 50 schools.
We are seeing the impact of these decisions today, with crumbling classrooms symptomatic of the years of neglect and failure we’ve faced under consecutive Conservative governments.
School buildings are unsafe, the first week of term has been ruined for pupils and teachers, and parents are grappling with their children learning from home once more. All the while, the Education Secretary wants parents to thank her for her hard work.
The Government needs to stop failing the next generation and get a grip on this crisis.

Earthquakes in Turkey and Syria
The scenes from the earthquakes in Turkey and Syria are heartbreaking.
The human toll of this disaster is immense. Thousands are already confirmed dead with that number expected to rise; infrastructure has been flattened; and hundreds remain trapped in buildings that have collapsed.
My thoughts are with all those impacted by this tragedy, including people in Enfield Southgate with family and friends in the region.
As a member of the Shadow Foreign Affairs team, I’ve been supporting calls for Britain to play its full part in assisting in the emergency and ensuring that families in the UK are kept informed about the safety of their relatives in the region. I welcome the FCDO’s decision to send a team of search and rescue specialists, equipment and rescue dogs to Turkey and its continued co-ordination with the UN in support of those in Syria.
Emergency appeals and information on donations
Following the earthquakes, I know people in our community are concerned about the situation in Turkey and Syria. Several charities and organisations have launched appeals and are providing support on the ground, and you can find some information on this below.
Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) charities and their local partners are among the first responders providing urgent help. Immediate priorities are search and rescue, medical treatment for the injured, shelter for those who have lost their homes, heating in safe spaces, blankets, warm clothes, and ensuring people have food and clean water.
More information on the DEC appeal here: https://www.dec.org.uk/appeal/turkey-syria-earthquake-appeal
Red Cross Turkey Syria Earthquake Appeal: https://donate.redcross.org.uk/appeal/turkey-syria-earthquake-appeal
Islamic Relief Turkiye Syria Earthquake Appeal: https://www.islamic-relief.org.uk/giving/appeals/turkiye-syria-earthquake-appeal/
Oxfam Turkey and Syria Earthquake Appeal: https://www.oxfam.org.uk/oxfam-in-action/current-emergencies/turkey-and-syria-earthquake-appeal/
Save the Children: https://www.savethechildren.org.uk/how-you-can-help/emergencies/turkey-syria-earthquake
The situation in Syria is incredibly concerning. People in Syria are already traumatised by over a decade of war, humanitarian crisis, and multiple displacements. The White Helmets are responding to the earthquake on the ground and urgently need support. Click here to support their emergency response in Syria: https://www.whitehelmets.org/en/?akid=6709.797951.06aTjp&rd=1&t=7
British Alevi Federation appeal: https://www.twitter.com/BAFederation/status/1622710426025820160
Enfield Council appeal and local donations
There has been an incredible response from our local community with donation points across the borough. Many of these collection points have reached full capacity and are unable to take further items.
Several Enfield community organisations are also collecting monetary donations. Please donate to those if they are organisations that you recognise and trust.

I was proud to join thousands of people at the demonstration in London over the weekend showing solidarity with the people of Ukraine. I was joined by Deputy Mayor of London Joanne McCartney and it was incredibly moving to see the scale of support from Londoners.
London and Enfield stands with Ukraine.

Earlier this week, I also had the pleasure of visiting Chase Farm Hospital and meeting staff who have worked throughout the pandemic to protect us. A huge thank you to all the NHS staff in Enfield and across the UK for everything that you’ve done during the pandemic and continue to do.

I was delighted to make my first visit to Israel this week as Shadow Minister for the Middle East and North Africa with Labour Friends of Israel and to speak at the UK-Israel Strategic Dialogue.
The busy itinerary which you can read about below left me with a deeper understanding of Israeli perspectives, the importance of a two state solution, and the opportunities and challenges faced by the broader Middle East region.
I also look forward to joining a delegation to Palestine later this spring to visit East Jerusalem and the West Bank.
On my first day I visited Yad Vashem to commemorate the victims of the Holocaust and lay a wreath on behalf of the Labour Party, and I later met with Israel’s deputy foreign minister Idan Roll to discuss the peace process and regional security challenges.
Throughout my trip I also met with a number of civil society organisations such as MEET education and Darkenu who do important work locally.
Day 2 included visits to Israel’s borders with Syria and Lebanon and a security briefing looking at the role of the UN Disengagement Observer Force.
On Day 3, I visited the Peres Center for Peace and Innovation in Tel Aviv before meeting Israeli Ambassador to the UK Tzipi Hotovely and the British Ambassador to Israel Neil Wigan. It was great to meet both in person and I look forward to continuing this important dialogue.
I also had the pleasure of meeting colleagues from Labour’s sister parties in Israel, Havoda and Meretz, during the trip. I heard about their place in Israel’s governing coalition and it also provided an opportunity to renew ties between the British Labour Party and the Israeli left.
The final day focused on the UK-Israel Strategic Dialogue with Chatham House and ELNET, and I was proud to speak on behalf of Labour and reaffirm our steadfast commitment to a negotiated, diplomatic settlement to the Israel-Palestinian conflict based on two states: a safe and secure Israel, alongside a viable and sovereign Palestinian state.

Haringey Civic Centre Groundbreaking Ceremony
Yesterday, I attended the groundbreaking ceremony of Haringey Civic Centre’s restoration.
Marking the redevelopment of the civic centre is an exciting step towards improving the sustainability of Haringey Council’s offices and access to residents and visitors to ready the building for the future. The redevelopment will ensure the Civic Centre reopens with a larger footprint to serve residents as a hub for Council services and offer public cultural spaces.
It is also wonderful to see how the Council have used the online consultation, Civic Voices, to engage with local residents and use their views to design this new and improved Civic Centre, while preserving history and celebrating important memories.

/in Enfield Southgate, News /by Bambos6th January 2021 –
Dentists across Enfield Southgate have contacted me about the issues they have been facing during the pandemic. They provide essential services that we all rely on and have worked hard to make their practices safe so they can continue to look after their patients.
I wrote to the Minster responsible for Dentistry, Jo Churchill MP, to raise these issues and aask how she will be working with NHS England to make sure our local dental practices, here in Enfield Southgate, don’t go bust.

There was an important policy announcement this week from Labour, as Anneliese Dodds and Angela Rayner outlined our new proposals to support women at work.
The next Labour Government will require large employers to produce action plans to support women going through the menopause. They will be required to write, publish and submit menopause action plans alongside their gender pay gap reporting each year.
Estimates suggest one million women who work during the menopause could leave their jobs in the next year alone due to their symptoms. These simple changes will mean employers can stop this from happening.

The UK must support the UN-brokered truce and provide humanitarian aid to civilians so a lasting peace can be built.

It was an honour to speak in Parliament to pay tribute to Queen Elizabeth II on behalf of people in Enfield Southgate.
In our grief, we remember a lifetime dedicated to extraordinary public service.
Looking back on her Coronation in 1953, Enfield celebrated just as we did for her Platinum Jubilee only a few months ago. Because for seventy years, she embodied and represented our nation, at home and abroad.
May she rest in peace.

I had the pleasure of meeting the families of British detainees being held in Iran in Parliament, including Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Anoosheh Ashoori’s families, alongside Amnesty International and my Labour colleagues Tulip Siddiq and Janet Daby.
As Shadow Minister for Middle East and North Africa, I pledged my support to do all we can to ensure the safe return of all the detainees.

On Monday, the Animal Welfare (Sentience) Bill returned to the House of Commons, and I know this is an issue that many people in our community care deeply about.
I have long supported calls to enshrine the principle of animal sentience in UK law and I welcomed this Bill, which will now become law.
But I do believe it is a missed opportunity to address long-standing animal welfare concerns, and I believe all animals deserve protection, whether they are pets, or live in the wild, in oceans or on farms. In my view the Government must continue to follow through on its promises for tougher laws.

I had the pleasure of visiting two wonderful local businesses on Small Business Saturday last weekend.
I visited Holtwhites Bakery, which has recently opened its new shop on Aldermans Hill in Palmers Green. I’m sure many of you know all about Holtwhites Bakery and its delicious, handmade bread, cakes and sandwiches, but be sure to support its new shop in Palmers Green!
I also popped into My Time, a local deli and organic café which does a great job showcasing local suppliers and products from across the borough.
Both of these shops highlight the success of our high street in Enfield Southgate. I will continue to support them as we enter the new year.

I know our community is full of animal lovers, so it was great to meet with Cats Protection recently to support their work protecting cats across the country. We also discussed issues constituents have raised with me, including enabling more people in rented housing to own pet cats.
I was also delighted to learn I won their Name the Giant Cat competition, with my Christmassy choice: Pudding!
A big thanks to the Cats Protection team for the early Christmas present and for all their work to improve cat welfare.

In 2019, there were 5,000 households in Enfield Southgate living in fuel poverty. Today, even more are feeling the pinch, with inflation out of control and the cost of living soaring at the fastest rate in nearly 30 years.
On Thursday, the Government announced its woefully inadequate plan to help people in Enfield with rising bills: a buy now, pay later scheme, which loads costs on working families for years down the line. It’s increasingly clear that the Tories are the cost of living crisis.
Labour, in contrast, would keep bills low and help fix the cost of living crisis with a windfall tax on oil and gas profits.

As Shadow Minister for the Middle East and North Africa, I spoke at the despatch box yesterday to call on the Government to stand up for human rights and help secure the release of political prisoners detained in Bahrain.
On the eve of a free trade agreement with Bahrain, the UK cannot remain silent and turn a blind eye when it comes to human rights.

I am very concerned about the impact of ending free lateral flow testing for care home visitors, which is set to start in April.
Many constituents have contacted me to say they feel they are being priced out of being responsible and should not have to pay to visit their loved ones – especially as we face a spiralling cost of living crisis. I’ve written to the Health Secretary this week to urge him to keep lateral flow testing free for care home visits.

I visited Great Northern’s depot for a ‘behind the scenes’ look at the new high-tech digital signalling system which will be operational on all 717trains going through Enfield Southgate in the next few years. I even got to try my hand at the simulator.
As a commuter myself, it was also good to hear about the new timetable that will be in operation from Sunday 15th May.

I spoke on behalf of the Shadow Foreign Affairs team following the horrific massacre at a church in south-west Nigeria. All should be free to worship in peace and I extended my solidarity to the victims and their families, as well as Nigerian communities here in Britain and the millions of Catholics around the word impacted by this attack.

Question to the Leader of the House
On 9th January 2025, I asked the Leader of the House for a debate in Government time to discuss the 3.3 billion people living in debt distressed countries where more is spent on debt servicing than on health and education combined. Listen to my question here:

Barnet and Southgate College’s New T-Level Centre
As part of T-Levels Week, on the 6th of December, I had the pleasure of opening the new T-Level Centre at Barnet and Southgate College’s Southgate campus. The newly refurbished centre will act as a hub for developing the workforce of tomorrow with facilities for teaching Engineering, Computing and IT, and Healthcare Science.
Studies here will be supported by state-of-the-art healthcare facilities and T-Level tutor experts to aid students in their courses.
Well done to Neil Coker, their CEO and principal, and all of his colleagues at Barnet and Southgate College! Good luck to all of the students who go on to study their T-Levels here!

I’m delighted to support Oxfam’s Second Hand September campaign this month, to help slow down fast fashion and protect our planet. Ahead of COP26, it’s crucial we raise awareness about fast fashion – with the textile industry accounting for 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
The campaign encourages all of us to buy second hand clothes and donate items to charity.
Here I am wearing my £7.50 second hand suit from North London Hospice in Palmers Green in support of Oxfam’s campaign.

It’s the 74th anniversary of the NHS, and I pay tribute to the amazing NHS staff who continue to deliver lifesaving work.
The Labour Party will always protect our NHS and stand up for its committed staff so that they can protect you and your family when you need it most.
Founded by the Labour Party, it has transformed people’s lives, giving access to world-class healthcare from the first to the last day of their lives.

Meeting with the Global Partnership for Education
As the Chair of the APPG for Global Education, it was wonderful to meet Laura Frigenti, the CEO of the Global Partnership for Education, in Parliament.
We discussed the importance of quality education for improving life chances worldwide and the need for international support.
I was proud to commit both mine and the APPG’s support for GPE.

In Westminster, it was another turbulent week for the Government, as the much-anticipated report into Downing Street parties was published by Sue Gray. While it was only an update, and not the full report, it was still incredibly damaging for Boris Johnson and the Conservatives.
It found there were “failures of leadership and judgement” at the heart of Government. It also confirmed that 12 gatherings are currently subject to investigation by the Metropolitan Police, which means that there is evidence of serious and flagrant breaches of lockdown rules.
It cannot be one rule for them and one rule for everyone else, and I will continue to call for Boris Johnson to resign, as well as for the full Sue Gray report, including findings from the Metropolitan Police, to be made public as soon as possible.

While it has taken months for the Afghan Citizens’ Resettlement Scheme to be opened, I welcomed its introduction as my office has been supporting several Chevening alumni connected to our constituency who remain stranded and in desperate need of our help.
The scheme must be a success but issues around family reunion, integration and safe passage from third countries remain.

Post-Brexit trade problems
The government continues to play down the impact of their failure to secure ‘frictionless trade’ post-Brexit.
All animal and plant products heading from the UK to EU markets now need an export health certificate signed off by an authorised veterinarian. But reports of shortages of customs agents, and concerns about a lack of vets to certify the expected increase in these certificates, shows the government are completely unprepared. Meat and fish exporters have been hit hard by costly delays at the border. The lull in January border traffic is expected to pick up again with the potential to cause a second wave of border chaos, ramping up from 2,000 lorries per day crossing between Dover and Calais to 10,000 per day.
I asked the Environment Secretary, George Eustice what steps the government is taking to prevent more delays and costs to the food and drink exporters.
The government continues to downplay the impact of their failure to secure ‘frictionless trade’ post-Brexit.
Exporters have been hit hard by costly delays at the border. I asked the Environment sec what the government is doing about it… 👇🏾 pic.twitter.com/ovFmwth8YB
— Bambos Charalambous MP (@Bambos_MP) January 21, 2021

I had the pleasure of visiting Broomfield School while on Recess, for an engaging Q&A with members of the school’s debating society. We discussed my role as an MP as well as the impact of Covid-19 on young people. Thank you to students and staff, and best of luck in the School’s Mace debating competition in November.

I hope you’ve all been enjoying the snow we’ve had, which has definitely dialled up the festive spirit.
But as the cost of living crisis grows for people in our community, it will be the most vulnerable who are worst affected by this cold spell. It is vital therefore that people are aware of support available this winter.
A cold weather payment has been introduced for Enfield Southgate, from EN1 to N22, following the snow. You can find out more details about the payment and see if you’re eligible below.
To help people through the cost of living crisis, I have been regularly updating my advice page which outlines a range of support that constituents may be eligible for, including government schemes, grants, information from local organisations, charities and more.

This week the Conservatives voted through the Health and Care Bill. This is the wrong Bill at the wrong time; it is an unnecessary distraction that won’t fix the crisis in our NHS, which has been created by over a decade of Tory cuts.
Measures in the Bill will let private companies have a say in the running of our NHS and force the poorest to sell their homes to pay for social care costs.
I know many constituents were concerned about this Bill and I voted against these measures alongside my Labour colleagues.

Ofgem has announced an energy price cap rise that almost triples bills since last winter. This will be a social and economic disaster, and I know people in our community are seriously worried about being able to pay their energy bills in the weeks and months ahead.
Indeed, according to new research, Enfield is among the hardest-hit areas in the country for rising energy bills and has more “energy crisis hotspots” than anywhere else in London.
That’s why I’ve been calling for immediate action – through freezing the energy price cap – so the burden of inflated energy prices does not fall on people in our community while the big energy companies make eye-watering profits.

This year is the 100th anniversary of the first St John Ambulance cadets in England, and it was great to visit the St John Ambulance training centre in Enfield to give out awards to local cadets.
Many thanks to David, Hector and Jackie on doing such an amazing job with the cadets.

I had the pleasure of joining the Love Your Doorstep team at New Scotland Yard to celebrate their community patrol volunteers.
In its fourth year now, the patrols help keep Enfield safe for our young people after school. I look forward to continuing to support this excellent community project.

Following the Planning Committee held on 23 June to decide if re-development of the Southgate Office Village (SOV) site in Chase Road, London N14 6HF should go forward, residents of Enfield Southgate and myself were pleased to hear that the vote unanimously rejected the plans. Viewpoint Estates have since appealed this decision and an inquiry is currently underway with the Planning Inspectorate.
During my evidence session yesterday, I supported that a town must evolve, however this must be done in a manner that is in the interests of residents now and in the future, and should not take away more than it contributes.
Following on from many conversations with constituents over the last two years, I raised the following concerns with the Inquiry:
- The proposed 17-storey height is excessive, an overdevelopment and out of character for the area, especially as this would be on a hill top in an area where no other developments are higher than six-storeys.
- This proposal would result in overdevelopment and local infrastructure would not be able to keep pace with the added pressure likely to be placed on for example, schools and GPs surgeries.
- The development is close to a conservation area and the proximity would adversely impact on views and light for surrounding properties;
- There is a lack of genuinely affordable accommodation and much of the development will comprise one-bedroom flats, which does not meet the need in the area for housing for local families.
Following on from the Council organised Planning panel meeting, constituents of Enfield Southgate have made the strength of their objections clear since that time, and I fully support them in their objections on the above grounds.
The Inquiry Inspector brought attention to the housing crisis and a need to build new homes. Whilst I agreed that there is a severe shortage of housing, the development does not meet the need for housing with three or more bedrooms to assist families. Southgate Office Village comprises 206 housing units with only 16 of those proposed to be 3 bedrooms, with 190 1-2 bed units. With over 3000 homeless families in the borough, this proposal does not contribute to our community or provide an affordable solution to the housing crisis.
I hoped to amplify the voice of constituents and to safeguard the needs of residents in response to this proposal; I asked that the Inquiry listens to my constituents and our community.

I have absolutely no confidence in this Government or this Prime Minister, and I voted to get rid of Boris Johnson now. From the messages and conversations I’ve had in recent weeks and months, I know people in Enfield Southgate do not have confidence in this Government either.
However, despite pushing him out earlier this month, Conservative MPs voted to keep Boris Johnson in Number 10 for now – at a time when the country needs honest and respected leadership.
After 12 years of broken promises, it’s time for a change, not just shifting the deckchairs at the top of a sinking Conservative party. We need a General Election now.

In 1933, the Piccadilly Line extension to Southgate and Cockfosters was opened. 90 years on, these iconic art deco stations designed by Charles Holden still keep us connected.
In my maiden speech in 2017, I paid tribute to our local tube stations which have made Enfield Southgate the place it is today.
I am delighted that Southgate District Civic Voice and others have organised a 90th anniversary celebration for Southgate Station. You can find more information about this below.

It was great to be up in Wakefield yesterday getting the vote out for Simon Lightwood, where volunteers from across the country were out campaigning for a Labour gain.
I’m absolutely delighted about this decisive result, which shows Labour is winning the trust of the British people and is firmly on the path to power while the Conservatives implode.

In Parliament, I raised the slow progress of the Afghan Citizens’ Resettlement Scheme again. And again, the Minister said the scheme is ‘in the process of being built’. This is unacceptable and time is running out for the Government to provide safe routes for people fleeing Afghanistan.

Women and girls in Iran are bravely putting their lives on the line after the death of Mahsa Amini. The UK must support all those standing up for basic freedoms, by encouraging press freedom in Iran and putting pressure on the Iranian regime in support of fundamental human rights.
On Tuesday, I asked the Minister what action the UK is taking as the crisis in Iran continues.

There was perfect weather and a big turnout for the Eversley Primary summer fete. Also lots of fab prizes for the raffle and tombola, fun bouncy castles and rides, but the highlight of the day was definitely the sliming of Ms Williams!
A big thank you to teachers, organisers and pupils for putting together a great event.

It was Christmas Jumper Day and I was proud to support Save The Children and their campaign to help the most vulnerable children in the UK and around the world.
I know local schools and businesses will have also joined in to support this great cause.

Justice Questions
Today, during Justice Questions, I asked the Minister for Courts what attention the Government had to offer the state of the court estate, as many courts are not operating due to ongoing repairs. This question follows a visit from the Minister for Sentencing to Wood Green Crown Court in December, on which I was pleased to join him.
I was glad to hear that the Government are serious about tackling court delays, whatever the cause.
Justice delayed is justice denied.
